Chapter 29.29:1: This is what you are to do to Aaron and his sons to dedicate them as priests in my service. Take one young bull and two rams without any defects.

Chapter 29.29:11: Kill the bull there in my holy presence at the entrance of the Tent.

Chapter 29.29:16: Kill it, and take its blood and throw it against all four sides of the altar.

Chapter 29.29:17: Cut the ram in pieces; wash its internal organs and its hind legs, and put them on top of the head and the other pieces.

Chapter 29.29:18: Burn the whole ram on the altar as a food offering. The odor of this offering pleases me.

Chapter 29.29:19: Take the other ram—the ram used for dedication—and tell Aaron and his sons to put their hands on its head.

Chapter 29.29:20: Kill it, and take some of its blood and put it on the lobes of the right ears of Aaron and his sons, on the thumbs of their right hands and on the big toes of their right feet. Throw the rest of the blood against all four sides of the altar.

Chapter 29.29:22: Cut away the ram's fat, the fat tail, the fat covering the internal organs, the best part of the liver, the two kidneys with the fat on them, and the right thigh.

Chapter 34.34:1: The Lord said to Moses, Cut two stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on them the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke.

Chapter 34.34:11: Obey the laws that I am giving you today. I will drive out the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, as you advance.

Chapter 34.34:12: Do not make any treaties with the people of the country into which you are going, because this could be a fatal trap for you.

Chapter 34.34:13: Instead, tear down their altars, destroy their sacred pillars, and cut down their symbols of the goddess Asherah.

Chapter 34.34:14: Do not worship any other god, because I, the Lord, tolerate no rivals.

Chapter 34.34:17: Do not make gods of metal and worship them.

Chapter 9.9:5: It is not because you are good and do what is right that the Lord is letting you take their land. He will drive them out because they are wicked and because he intends to keep the promise that he made to your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

Chapter 9.9:6: You can be sure that the Lord is not giving you this fertile land because you deserve it. No, you are a stubborn people.

Chapter 9.9:7: Never forget how you made the Lord your God angry in the desert. From the day that you left Egypt until the day you arrived here, you have rebelled against him.

Chapter 9.9:8: Even at Mount Sinai you made the Lord angry—angry enough to destroy you.

Chapter 9.9:9: I went up the mountain to receive the stone tablets on which was written the covenant that the Lord had made with you. I stayed there forty days and nights and did not eat or drink anything.

Chapter 9.9:10: Then the Lord gave me the two stone tablets on which he had written with his own hand what he had said to you from the fire on the day that you were gathered there at the mountain.

Chapter 9.9:11: Yes, after those forty days and nights the Lord gave me the two stone tablets on which he had written the covenant.

Chapter 9.9:12: Then the Lord said to me, Go down the mountain at once, because your people, whom you led out of Egypt, have become corrupt and have done evil. They have already turned away from what I commanded them to do, and they have made an idol for themselves.

Chapter 9.9:13: The Lord also said to me, I know how stubborn these people are.

Chapter 9.9:14: Don't try to stop me. I intend to destroy them so that no one will remember them any longer. Then I will make you the father of a nation larger and more powerful than they are.

Chapter 9.9:15: So I turned and went down the mountain, carrying the two stone tablets on which the covenant was written. Flames of fire were coming from the mountain.

Chapter 9.9:16: I saw that you had already disobeyed the command that the Lord your God had given you, and that you had sinned against him by making yourselves a metal idol in the form of a bull-calf.

Chapter 9.9:17: So there in front of you I threw the stone tablets down and broke them to pieces.

Chapter 9.9:18: Then once again I lay face downward in the Lord's presence for forty days and nights and did not eat or drink anything. I did this because you had sinned against the Lord and had made him angry.

Chapter 9.9:19: I was afraid of the Lord's fierce anger, because he was furious enough to destroy you; but once again the Lord listened to me.

Chapter 9.9:20: The Lord was also angry enough with Aaron to kill him, so I prayed for Aaron at the same time.

Chapter 9.9:21: I took that sinful thing that you had made—that metal bull-calf—and threw it into the fire. Then I broke it in pieces, ground it to dust, and threw the dust into the stream that flowed down the mountain.

Chapter 9.9:22: You also made the Lord your God angry when you were at Taberah, Massah, and Kibroth Hattaavah.

Chapter 9.9:23: And when he sent you from Kadesh Barnea with orders to go and take possession of the land that he was giving you, you rebelled against him; you did not trust him or obey him.

Chapter 9.9:24: Ever since I have known you, you have rebelled against the Lord.

Chapter 9.9:25: So I lay face downward in the Lord's presence those forty days and nights, because I knew that he was determined to destroy you.

Chapter 9.9:26: And I prayed, Sovereign Lord, don't destroy your own people, the people you rescued and brought out of Egypt by your great strength and power.

Chapter 9.9:27: Remember your servants, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and do not pay any attention to the stubbornness, wickedness, and sin of this people.

Chapter 9.9:28: Otherwise, the Egyptians will say that you were unable to take your people into the land that you had promised them. They will say that you took your people out into the desert to kill them, because you hated them.

Chapter 9.9:29: After all, these are the people whom you chose to be your own and whom you brought out of Egypt by your great power and might.

Chapter 10.10:1: Then the Lord said to me, Cut two stone tablets like the first ones and make a wooden Box to put them in. Come up to me on the mountain,

Chapter 10.10:11: Then he told me to go and lead you, so that you could take possession of the land that he had promised to give to your ancestors.

Chapter 10.10:12: Now, people of Israel, listen to what the Lord your God demands of you: Worship the Lord and do all that he commands. Love him, serve him with all your heart,

Chapter 10.10:14: To the Lord belong even the highest heavens; the earth is his also, and everything on it.

Chapter 10.10:15: But the Lord's love for your ancestors was so strong that he chose you instead of any other people, and you are still his chosen people.

Chapter 10.10:16: So then, from now on be obedient to the Lord and stop being stubborn.

Chapter 10.10:17: The Lord your God is supreme over all gods and over all powers. He is great and mighty, and he is to be obeyed. He does not show partiality, and he does not accept bribes.

Chapter 10.10:18: He makes sure that orphans and widows are treated fairly; he loves the foreigners who live with our people, and gives them food and clothes.

Chapter 10.10:19: So then, show love for those foreigners, because you were once foreigners in Egypt.

Chapter 10.10:20: Have reverence for the Lord your God and worship only him. Be faithful to him and make your promises in his name alone.

Chapter 10.10:21: Praise him—he is your God, and you have seen with your own eyes the great and astounding things that he has done for you.

Chapter 10.10:22: When your ancestors went to Egypt, there were only seventy of them. But now the Lord your God has made you as numerous as the stars in the sky.

Chapter 11.11:1: Love the Lord your God and always obey all his laws.

Chapter 11.11:2: Remember today what you have learned about the Lord through your experiences with him. It was you, not your children, who had these experiences. You saw the Lord's greatness, his power, his might,

Chapter 11.11:3: and his miracles. You saw what he did to the king of Egypt and to his entire country.

Chapter 11.11:4: You saw how the Lord completely wiped out the Egyptian army, along with their horses and chariots, by drowning them in the Red Sea when they were pursuing you.

Chapter 11.11:5: You know what the Lord did for you in the desert before you arrived here.

Chapter 11.11:6: You recall what he did to Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab of the tribe of Reuben. In the sight of everyone the earth opened up and swallowed them, along with their families, their tents, and all their servants and animals.

Chapter 11.11:7: Yes, you are the ones who have seen all these great things that the Lord has done.

Chapter 11.11:8: Obey everything that I have commanded you today. Then you will be able to cross the river and occupy the land that you are about to enter.

Chapter 11.11:9: And you will live a long time in the rich and fertile land that the Lord promised to give your ancestors and their descendants.

Chapter 11.11:10: The land that you are about to occupy is not like the land of Egypt, where you lived before. There, when you planted grain, you had to work hard to irrigate the fields;

Chapter 11.11:11: but the land that you are about to enter is a land of mountains and valleys, a land watered by rain.

Chapter 11.11:12: The Lord your God takes care of this land and watches over it throughout the year.

Chapter 11.11:13: So then, obey the commands that I have given you today; love the Lord your God and serve him with all your heart.

Chapter 11.11:14: If you do, he will send rain on your land when it is needed, in the autumn and in the spring, so that there will be grain, wine, and olive oil for you,

Chapter 11.11:15: and grass for your livestock. You will have all the food you want.

Chapter 11.11:16: Do not let yourselves be led away from the Lord to worship and serve other gods.

Chapter 11.11:17: If you do, the Lord will become angry with you. He will hold back the rain, and your ground will become too dry for crops to grow. Then you will soon die there, even though it is a good land that he is giving you.

Chapter 11.11:18: Remember these commands and cherish them. Tie them on your arms and wear them on your foreheads as a reminder.

Chapter 11.11:19: Teach them to your children. Talk about them when you are at home and when you are away, when you are resting and when you are working.

Chapter 11.11:20: Write them on the doorposts of your houses and on your gates.

Chapter 11.11:21: Then you and your children will live a long time in the land that the Lord your God promised to give to your ancestors. You will live there as long as there is a sky above the earth.

Chapter 11.11:22: Obey faithfully everything that I have commanded you: Love the Lord your God, do everything he commands, and be faithful to him.

Chapter 11.11:23: Then he will drive out all those nations as you advance, and you will occupy the land belonging to nations greater and more powerful than you.

Chapter 11.11:24: All the ground that you march over will be yours. Your territory will extend from the desert in the south to the Lebanon Mountains in the north, and from the Euphrates River in the east to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.

Chapter 11.11:25: Wherever you go in that land, the Lord your God will make the people fear you, as he has promised, and no one will be able to stop you.

Chapter 11.11:26: Today I am giving you the choice between a blessing and a curse—

Chapter 11.11:27: a blessing, if you obey the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today;

Chapter 11.11:28: but a curse, if you disobey these commands and turn away to worship other gods that you have never worshiped before.

Chapter 11.11:29: When the Lord brings you into the land that you are going to occupy, you are to proclaim the blessing from Mount Gerizim and the curse from Mount Ebal.

Chapter 11.11:30: These two mountains are west of the Jordan River in the territory of the Canaanites who live in the Jordan Valley. They are toward the west, not far from the sacred trees of Moreh near the town of Gilgal.

Chapter 11.11:31: You are about to cross the Jordan River and occupy the land that the Lord your God is giving you. When you take it and settle there,

Chapter 11.11:32: be sure to obey all the laws that I am giving you today.

Chapter 12.12:1: Here are the laws that you are to obey as long as you live in the land that the Lord, the God of your ancestors, is giving you. Listen to them!

Chapter 12.12:3: Tear down their altars and smash their sacred stone pillars to pieces. Burn their symbols of the goddess Asherah and chop down their idols, so that they will never again be worshiped at those places.

Chapter 12.12:4: Do not worship the Lord your God in the way that these people worship their gods.

Chapter 12.12:5: Out of the territory of all your tribes the Lord will choose the one place where the people are to come into his presence and worship him.

Chapter 12.12:6: There you are to offer your sacrifices that are to be burned and your other sacrifices, your tithes and your offerings, the gifts that you promise to the Lord, your freewill offerings, and the first-born of your cattle and sheep.

Chapter 12.12:7: There, in the presence of the Lord your God, who has blessed you, you and your families will eat and enjoy the good things that you have worked for.

Chapter 12.12:8: When that time comes, you must not do as you have been doing. Until now you have all been worshiping as you please,

Chapter 12.12:9: because you have not yet entered the land that the Lord your God is giving you, where you can live in peace.

Chapter 12.12:10: When you cross the Jordan River, the Lord will let you occupy the land and live there. He will keep you safe from all your enemies, and you will live in peace.

Chapter 12.12:11: The Lord will choose a single place where he is to be worshiped, and there you must bring to him everything that I have commanded: your sacrifices that are to be burned and your other sacrifices, your tithes and your offerings, and those special gifts that you have promised to the Lord.

Chapter 12.12:12: Be joyful there in his presence, together with your children, your servants, and the Levites who live in your towns; remember that the Levites will have no land of their own.

Chapter 12.12:13: You are not to offer your sacrifices wherever you choose;

Chapter 12.12:15: But you are free to kill and eat your animals wherever you live. You may eat as many as the Lord gives you. All of you, whether ritually clean or unclean, may eat them, just as you would eat the meat of deer or antelope.

Chapter 12.12:17: Nothing that you offer to the Lord is to be eaten in the places where you live: neither the tithes of your grain, your wine, or your olive oil, nor the first-born of your cattle and sheep, the gifts that you promise to the Lord, your freewill offerings, or any other offerings.

Chapter 12.12:18: You and your children, together with your servants and the Levites who live in your towns, are to eat these offerings only in the presence of the Lord your God, in the one place of worship chosen by the Lord your God. Chapter 12.12:19: Be sure, also, not to neglect the Levites, as long as you live in your land.

Chapter 12.12:20: When the Lord your God enlarges your territory, as he has promised, you may eat meat whenever you want to.

Chapter 12.12:21: If the one place of worship is too far away, then, whenever you wish, you may kill any of the cattle or sheep that the Lord has given you, and you may eat the meat at home, as I have told you.

Chapter 12.12:22: Anyone, ritually clean or unclean, may eat that meat, just as he would eat the meat of deer or antelope.

Chapter 12.12:23: Only do not eat meat with blood still in it, for the life is in the blood, and you must not eat the life with the meat.

Chapter 12.12:24: Do not use the blood for food; instead, pour it out on the ground like water.

Chapter 12.12:25: If you obey this command, the Lord will be pleased, and all will go well for you and your descendants.

Chapter 12.12:26: Take to the one place of worship your offerings and the gifts that you have promised the Lord.

Chapter 12.12:27: Offer there the sacrifices which are to be completely burned on the Lord's altar. Also offer those sacrifices in which you eat the meat and pour the blood out on the altar.

Chapter 12.12:28: Obey faithfully everything that I have commanded you, and all will go well for you and your descendants forever, because you will be doing what is right and what pleases the Lord your God.

Chapter 12.12:29: The Lord your God will destroy the nations as you invade their land, and you will occupy it and settle there.

Chapter 12.12:30: After the Lord destroys those nations, make sure that you don't follow their religious practices, because that would be fatal. Don't try to find out how they worship their gods, so that you can worship in the same way.

Chapter 12.12:31: Do not worship the Lord your God in the way they worship their gods, for in the worship of their gods they do all the disgusting things that the Lord hates. They even sacrifice their children in the fires on their altars.

Chapter 12.12:32: Do everything that I have commanded you; do not add anything to it or take anything from it.

Chapter 14.14:1: Homes are made by the wisdom of women, but are destroyed by foolishness.

Chapter 14.14:2: Be honest and you show that you have reverence for the Lord; be dishonest and you show that you do not.

Chapter 14.14:3: Proud fools talk too much; the words of the wise protect them.

Chapter 14.14:4: Without any oxen to pull the plow your barn will be empty, but with them it will be full of grain.

Chapter 14.14:5: A reliable witness always tells the truth, but an unreliable one tells nothing but lies.

Chapter 14.14:6: Conceited people can never become wise, but intelligent people learn easily.

Chapter 14.14:7: Stay away from foolish people; they have nothing to teach you.

Chapter 14.14:8: Why is a clever person wise? Because he knows what to do. Why is a stupid person foolish? Because he only thinks he knows.

Chapter 14.14:9: Foolish people don't care if they sin, but good people want to be forgiven.

Chapter 14.14:10: Your joy is your own; your bitterness is your own. No one can share them with you.

Chapter 14.14:11: A good person's house will still be standing after an evildoer's house has been destroyed.

Chapter 14.14:12: What you think is the right road may lead to death.

Chapter 14.14:13: Laughter may hide sadness. When happiness is gone, sorrow is always there.

Chapter 14.14:14: Bad people will get what they deserve. Good people will be rewarded for their deeds.

Chapter 14.14:15: A fool will believe anything; smart people watch their step.

Chapter 14.14:16: Sensible people are careful to stay out of trouble, but stupid people are careless and act too quickly.

Chapter 14.14:17: People with a hot temper do foolish things; wiser people remain calm.

Chapter 14.14:18: Ignorant people get what their foolishness deserves, but the clever are rewarded with knowledge.

Chapter 14.14:19: Evil people will have to bow down to the righteous and humbly beg their favor.

Chapter 14.14:20: No one likes the poor, not even their neighbors, but the rich have many friends.

Chapter 14.14:21: If you want to be happy, be kind to the poor; it is a sin to despise anyone.

Chapter 14.14:22: You will earn the trust and respect of others if you work for good; if you work for evil, you are making a mistake.

Chapter 14.14:23: Work and you will earn a living; if you sit around talking you will be poor.

Chapter 14.14:24: Wise people are rewarded with wealth, but fools are known by their foolishness.

Chapter 14.14:25: A witness saves lives when he tells the truth; when he tells lies, he betrays people.

Chapter 14.14:26: Reverence for the Lord gives confidence and security to a man and his family.

Chapter 14.14:27: Do you want to avoid death? Reverence for the Lord is a fountain of life.

Chapter 14.14:28: A king's greatness depends on how many people he rules; without them he is nothing.

Chapter 14.14:29: If you stay calm, you are wise, but if you have a hot temper, you only show how stupid you are.

Chapter 14.14:30: Peace of mind makes the body healthy, but jealousy is like a cancer.

Chapter 14.14:31: If you oppress poor people, you insult the God who made them; but kindness shown to the poor is an act of worship.

Chapter 14.14:32: Wicked people bring about their own downfall by their evil deeds, but good people are protected by their integrity.

Chapter 14.14:33: Wisdom is in every thought of intelligent people; fools know nothing about wisdom.

Chapter 14.14:34: Righteousness makes a nation great; sin is a disgrace to any nation.

Chapter 14.14:35: Kings are pleased with competent officials, but they punish those who fail them.

Chapter 15.15:1: A gentle answer quiets anger, but a harsh one stirs it up.

Chapter 15.15:2: When wise people speak, they make knowledge attractive, but stupid people spout nonsense.

Chapter 15.15:3: The Lord sees what happens everywhere; he is watching us, whether we do good or evil.

Chapter 15.15:4: Kind words bring life, but cruel words crush your spirit.

Chapter 15.15:5: It is foolish to ignore what your parents taught you; it is wise to accept their correction.

Chapter 15.15:6: Righteous people keep their wealth, but the wicked lose theirs when hard times come.

Chapter 15.15:7: Knowledge is spread by people who are wise, not by fools.

Chapter 15.15:8: The Lord is pleased when good people pray, but hates the sacrifices that the wicked bring him.

Chapter 15.15:9: The Lord hates the ways of evil people, but loves those who do what is right.

Chapter 15.15:10: If you do what is wrong, you will be severely punished; you will die if you do not let yourself be corrected.

Chapter 15.15:11: Not even the world of the dead can keep the Lord from knowing what is there; how then can we hide our thoughts from God?

Chapter 15.15:12: Conceited people do not like to be corrected; they never ask for advice from those who are wiser.

Chapter 15.15:13: When people are happy, they smile, but when they are sad, they look depressed.

Chapter 15.15:14: Intelligent people want to learn, but stupid people are satisfied with ignorance.

Chapter 15.15:15: The life of the poor is a constant struggle, but happy people always enjoy life.

Chapter 15.15:16: Better to be poor and fear the Lord than to be rich and in trouble.

Chapter 15.15:17: Better to eat vegetables with people you love than to eat the finest meat where there is hate.

Chapter 15.15:18: Hot tempers cause arguments, but patience brings peace.

Chapter 15.15:19: If you are lazy, you will meet difficulty everywhere, but if you are honest, you will have no trouble.

Chapter 15.15:20: Wise children make their fathers happy. Only fools despise their mothers.

Chapter 15.15:21: Stupid people are happy with their foolishness, but the wise will do what is right.

Chapter 15.15:22: Get all the advice you can, and you will succeed; without it you will fail.

Chapter 15.15:23: What a joy it is to find just the right word for the right occasion!

Chapter 15.15:24: Wise people walk the road that leads upward to life, not the road that leads downward to death.

Chapter 15.15:25: The Lord will destroy the homes of arrogant men, but he will protect a widow's property.

Chapter 15.15:26: The Lord hates evil thoughts, but he is pleased with friendly words.

Chapter 15.15:27: Try to make a profit dishonestly, and you get your family in trouble. Don't take bribes and you will live longer.

Chapter 15.15:28: Good people think before they answer. Evil people have a quick reply, but it causes trouble.

Chapter 15.15:29: When good people pray, the Lord listens, but he ignores those who are evil.

Chapter 15.15:30: Smiling faces make you happy, and good news makes you feel better.

Chapter 15.15:31: If you pay attention when you are corrected, you are wise.

Chapter 15.15:32: If you refuse to learn, you are hurting yourself. If you accept correction, you will become wiser.

Chapter 15.15:33: Reverence for the Lord is an education in itself. You must be humble before you can ever receive honors.

Chapter 16.16:1: We may make our plans, but God has the last word.

Chapter 16.16:2: You may think everything you do is right, but the Lord judges your motives.

Chapter 16.16:3: Ask the Lord to bless your plans, and you will be successful in carrying them out.

Chapter 16.16:4: Everything the Lord has made has its destiny; and the destiny of the wicked is destruction.

Chapter 16.16:5: The Lord hates everyone who is arrogant; he will never let them escape punishment.

Chapter 16.16:6: Be loyal and faithful, and God will forgive your sin. Obey the Lord and nothing evil will happen to you.

Chapter 16.16:7: When you please the Lord, you can make your enemies into friends.

Chapter 16.16:8: It is better to have a little, honestly earned, than to have a large income, dishonestly gained.

Chapter 16.16:9: You may make your plans, but God directs your actions.

Chapter 16.16:10: The king speaks with divine authority; his decisions are always right.

Chapter 16.16:11: The Lord wants weights and measures to be honest and every sale to be fair.

Chapter 16.16:12: Kings cannot tolerate evil, because justice is what makes a government strong.

Chapter 16.16:13: A king wants to hear the truth and will favor those who speak it.

Chapter 16.16:14: A wise person will try to keep the king happy; if the king becomes angry, someone may die.

Chapter 16.16:15: The king's favor is like the clouds that bring rain in the springtime—life is there.

Chapter 16.16:16: It is better—much better—to have wisdom and knowledge than gold and silver.

Chapter 16.16:17: Those who are good travel a road that avoids evil; so watch where you are going—it may save your life.

Chapter 16.16:18: Pride leads to destruction, and arrogance to downfall.

Chapter 16.16:19: It is better to be humble and stay poor than to be one of the arrogant and get a share of their loot.

Chapter 16.16:20: Pay attention to what you are taught, and you will be successful; trust in the Lord and you will be happy.

Chapter 16.16:21: A wise, mature person is known for his understanding. The more pleasant his words, the more persuasive he is.

Chapter 16.16:22: Wisdom is a fountain of life to the wise, but trying to educate stupid people is a waste of time.

Chapter 16.16:23: Intelligent people think before they speak; what they say is then more persuasive.

Chapter 16.16:24: Kind words are like honey—sweet to the taste and good for your health.

Chapter 16.16:25: What you think is the right road may lead to death.

Chapter 16.16:26: A laborer's appetite makes him work harder, because he wants to satisfy his hunger.

Chapter 16.16:27: Evil people look for ways to harm others; even their words burn with evil.

Chapter 16.16:28: Gossip is spread by wicked people; they stir up trouble and break up friendships.

Chapter 16.16:29: Violent people deceive their friends and lead them to disaster.

Chapter 16.16:30: Watch out for people who grin and wink at you; they have thought of something evil.

Chapter 16.16:31: Long life is the reward of the righteous; gray hair is a glorious crown.

Chapter 16.16:32: It is better to be patient than powerful. It is better to win control over yourself than over whole cities.

Chapter 16.16:33: People cast lots to learn God's will, but God himself determines the answer.

Chapter 17.17:1: Better to eat a dry crust of bread with peace of mind than have a banquet in a house full of trouble.

Chapter 17.17:2: A shrewd servant will gain authority over a master's worthless son and receive a part of the inheritance.

Chapter 17.17:3: Gold and silver are tested by fire, and a person's heart is tested by the Lord.

Chapter 17.17:4: Evil people listen to evil ideas, and liars listen to lies.

Chapter 17.17:5: If you make fun of poor people, you insult the God who made them. You will be punished if you take pleasure in someone's misfortune.

Chapter 17.17:6: Grandparents are proud of their grandchildren, just as children are proud of their parents.

Chapter 17.17:7: Respected people do not tell lies, and fools have nothing worthwhile to say.

Chapter 17.17:8: Some people think a bribe works like magic; they believe it can do anything.

Chapter 17.17:9: If you want people to like you, forgive them when they wrong you. Remembering wrongs can break up a friendship.

Chapter 17.17:10: An intelligent person learns more from one rebuke than a fool learns from being beaten a hundred times.

Chapter 17.17:11: Death will come like a cruel messenger to wicked people who are always stirring up trouble.

Chapter 17.17:12: It is better to meet a mother bear robbed of her cubs than to meet some fool busy with a stupid project.

Chapter 17.17:13: If you repay good with evil, you will never get evil out of your house.

Chapter 17.17:14: The start of an argument is like the first break in a dam; stop it before it goes any further.

Chapter 17.17:15: Condemning the innocent or letting the wicked go—both are hateful to the Lord.

Chapter 17.17:16: It does a fool no good to spend money on an education, because he has no common sense.

Chapter 17.17:17: Friends always show their love. What are relatives for if not to share trouble?

Chapter 17.17:18: Only someone with no sense would promise to be responsible for someone else's debts.

Chapter 17.17:19: To like sin is to like making trouble. If you brag all the time, you are asking for trouble.

Chapter 17.17:20: Anyone who thinks and speaks evil can expect to find nothing good—only disaster.

Chapter 17.17:21: There is nothing but sadness and sorrow for parents whose children do foolish things.

Chapter 17.17:22: Being cheerful keeps you healthy. It is slow death to be gloomy all the time.

Chapter 17.17:23: Corrupt judges accept secret bribes, and then justice is not done.

Chapter 17.17:24: An intelligent person aims at wise action, but a fool starts off in many directions.

Chapter 17.17:25: Foolish children bring grief to their fathers and bitter regrets to their mothers.

Chapter 17.17:26: It is not right to make an innocent person pay a fine; justice is perverted when good people are punished.

Chapter 17.17:27: Those who are sure of themselves do not talk all the time. People who stay calm have real insight.

Chapter 17.17:28: After all, even fools may be thought wise and intelligent if they stay quiet and keep their mouths shut.

Chapter 18.18:1: People who do not get along with others are interested only in themselves; they will disagree with what everyone else knows is right.

Chapter 18.18:2: A fool does not care whether he understands a thing or not; all he wants to do is show how smart he is.

Chapter 18.18:3: Sin and shame go together. Lose your honor, and you will get scorn in its place.

Chapter 18.18:4: A person's words can be a source of wisdom, deep as the ocean, fresh as a flowing stream.

Chapter 18.18:5: It is not right to favor the guilty and keep the innocent from receiving justice.

Chapter 18.18:6: When some fool starts an argument, he is asking for a beating.

Chapter 18.18:7: When a fool speaks, he is ruining himself; he gets caught in the trap of his own words.

Chapter 18.18:8: Gossip is so tasty—how we love to swallow it!

Chapter 18.18:9: A lazy person is as bad as someone who is destructive.

Chapter 18.18:10: The Lord is like a strong tower, where the righteous can go and be safe.

Chapter 18.18:11: Rich people, however, imagine that their wealth protects them like high, strong walls around a city.

Chapter 18.18:12: No one is respected unless he is humble; arrogant people are on the way to ruin.

Chapter 18.18:13: Listen before you answer. If you don't, you are being stupid and insulting.

Chapter 18.18:14: Your will to live can sustain you when you are sick, but if you lose it, your last hope is gone.

Chapter 18.18:15: Intelligent people are always eager and ready to learn.

Chapter 18.18:16: Do you want to meet an important person? Take a gift and it will be easy.

Chapter 18.18:17: The first person to speak in court always seems right until his opponent begins to question him.

Chapter 18.18:18: If two powerful people are opposing each other in court, casting lots can settle the issue.

Chapter 18.18:19: Help your relatives and they will protect you like a strong city wall, but if you quarrel with them, they will close their doors to you.

Chapter 18.18:20: You will have to live with the consequences of everything you say.

Chapter 18.18:21: What you say can preserve life or destroy it; so you must accept the consequences of your words.

Chapter 18.18:22: Find a wife and you find a good thing; it shows that the Lord is good to you.

Chapter 18.18:23: When the poor speak, they have to be polite, but when the rich answer, they are rude.

Chapter 18.18:24: Some friendships do not last, but some friends are more loyal than brothers.

Chapter 19.19:1: It is better to be poor but honest than to be a lying fool.

Chapter 19.19:2: Enthusiasm without knowledge is not good; impatience will get you into trouble.

Chapter 19.19:3: Some people ruin themselves by their own stupid actions and then blame the Lord.

Chapter 19.19:4: Rich people are always finding new friends, but the poor cannot keep the few they have.

Chapter 19.19:5: If you tell lies in court, you will be punished—there will be no escape.

Chapter 19.19:6: Everyone tries to gain the favor of important people; everyone claims the friendship of those who give out favors.

Chapter 19.19:7: Even the relatives of a poor person have no use for him; no wonder he has no friends. No matter how hard he tries, he cannot win any.

Chapter 19.19:8: Do yourself a favor and learn all you can; then remember what you learn and you will prosper.

Chapter 19.19:9: No one who tells lies in court can escape punishment; he is doomed.

Chapter 19.19:10: Fools should not live in luxury, and slaves should not rule over noblemen.

Chapter 19.19:11: If you are sensible, you will control your temper. When someone wrongs you, it is a great virtue to ignore it.

Chapter 19.19:12: The king's anger is like the roar of a lion, but his favor is like welcome rain.

Chapter 19.19:13: Stupid children can bring their parents to ruin. A nagging wife is like water going drip-drip-drip.

Chapter 19.19:14: A man can inherit a house and money from his parents, but only the Lord can give him a sensible wife.

Chapter 19.19:15: Go ahead and be lazy; sleep on, but you will go hungry.

Chapter 19.19:16: Keep God's laws and you will live longer; if you ignore them, you will die.

Chapter 19.19:17: When you give to the poor, it is like lending to the Lord, and the Lord will pay you back.

Chapter 19.19:18: Discipline your children while they are young enough to learn. If you don't, you are helping them destroy themselves.

Chapter 19.19:19: If someone has a hot temper, let him take the consequences. If you get him out of trouble once, you will have to do it again.

Chapter 19.19:20: If you listen to advice and are willing to learn, one day you will be wise.

Chapter 19.19:21: People may plan all kinds of things, but the Lord's will is going to be done.

Chapter 19.19:22: It is a disgrace to be greedy; poor people are better off than liars.

Chapter 19.19:23: Obey the Lord and you will live a long life, content and safe from harm.

Chapter 19.19:24: Some people are too lazy to put food in their own mouths.

Chapter 19.19:25: Arrogance should be punished, so that people who don't know any better can learn a lesson. If you are wise, you will learn when you are corrected.

Chapter 19.19:26: Only a shameful, disgraceful person would mistreat his father or turn his mother away from his home.

Chapter 19.19:27: My child, when you stop learning, you will soon neglect what you already know.

Chapter 19.19:28: There is no justice where a witness is determined to hurt someone. Wicked people love the taste of evil.

Chapter 19.19:29: A conceited fool is sure to get a beating.

Chapter 20.20:1: Drinking too much makes you loud and foolish. It's stupid to get drunk.

Chapter 20.20:2: Fear an angry king as you would a growling lion; making him angry is suicide.

Chapter 20.20:3: Any fool can start arguments; the honorable thing is to stay out of them.

Chapter 20.20:4: A farmer too lazy to plow his fields at the right time will have nothing to harvest.

Chapter 20.20:5: A person's thoughts are like water in a deep well, but someone with insight can draw them out.

Chapter 20.20:6: Everyone talks about how loyal and faithful he is, but just try to find someone who really is!

Chapter 20.20:7: Children are fortunate if they have a father who is honest and does what is right.

Chapter 20.20:8: The king sits in judgment and knows evil when he sees it.

Chapter 20.20:9: Can anyone really say that his conscience is clear, that he has gotten rid of his sin?

Chapter 20.20:10: The Lord hates people who use dishonest weights and measures.

Chapter 20.20:11: Even children show what they are by what they do; you can tell if they are honest and good.

Chapter 20.20:12: The Lord has given us eyes to see with and ears to listen with.

Chapter 20.20:13: If you spend your time sleeping, you will be poor. Keep busy and you will have plenty to eat.

Chapter 20.20:14: The customer always complains that the price is too high, but then he goes off and brags about the bargain he got.

Chapter 20.20:15: If you know what you are talking about, you have something more valuable than gold or jewels.

Chapter 20.20:16: Anyone stupid enough to promise to be responsible for a stranger's debts ought to have their own property held to guarantee payment.

Chapter 20.20:17: What you get by dishonesty you may enjoy like the finest food, but sooner or later it will be like a mouthful of sand.

Chapter 20.20:18: Get good advice and you will succeed; don't go charging into battle without a plan.

Chapter 20.20:19: A gossip can never keep a secret. Stay away from people who talk too much.

Chapter 20.20:20: If you curse your parents, your life will end like a lamp that goes out in the dark.

Chapter 20.20:21: The more easily you get your wealth, the less good it will do you.

Chapter 20.20:22: Don't take it on yourself to repay a wrong. Trust the Lord and he will make it right.

Chapter 20.20:23: The Lord hates people who use dishonest scales and weights.

Chapter 20.20:24: The Lord has determined our path; how then can anyone understand the direction his own life is taking?

Chapter 20.20:25: Think carefully before you promise an offering to God. You might regret it later.

Chapter 20.20:26: A wise king will find out who is doing wrong, and will punish him without pity.

Chapter 20.20:27: The Lord gave us mind and conscience; we cannot hide from ourselves.

Chapter 20.20:28: A king will remain in power as long as his rule is honest, just, and fair.

Chapter 20.20:29: We admire the strength of youth and respect the gray hair of age.

Chapter 20.20:30: Sometimes it takes a painful experience to make us change our ways.

Chapter 21.21:1: The Lord controls the mind of a king as easily as he directs the course of a stream.

Chapter 21.21:2: You may think that everything you do is right, but remember that the Lord judges your motives.

Chapter 21.21:3: Do what is right and fair; that pleases the Lord more than bringing him sacrifices.

Chapter 21.21:4: Wicked people are controlled by their conceit and arrogance, and this is sinful.

Chapter 21.21:5: Plan carefully and you will have plenty; if you act too quickly, you will never have enough.

Chapter 21.21:6: The riches you get by dishonesty soon disappear, but not before they lead you into the jaws of death.

Chapter 21.21:7: The wicked are doomed by their own violence; they refuse to do what is right.

Chapter 21.21:8: Guilty people walk a crooked path; the innocent do what is right.

Chapter 21.21:9: Better to live on the roof than share the house with a nagging wife.

Chapter 21.21:10: Wicked people are always hungry for evil; they have no mercy on anyone.

Chapter 21.21:11: When someone who is conceited gets his punishment, even an unthinking person learns a lesson. One who is wise will learn from what he is taught.

Chapter 21.21:12: God, the righteous one, knows what goes on in the homes of the wicked, and he will bring the wicked down to ruin.

Chapter 21.21:13: If you refuse to listen to the cry of the poor, your own cry for help will not be heard.

Chapter 21.21:14: If someone is angry with you, a gift given secretly will calm him down.

Chapter 21.21:15: When justice is done, good people are happy, but evil people are brought to despair.

Chapter 21.21:16: Death is waiting for anyone who wanders away from good sense.

Chapter 21.21:17: Indulging in luxuries, wine, and rich food will never make you wealthy.

Chapter 21.21:18: The wicked bring on themselves the suffering they try to cause good people.

Chapter 21.21:19: Better to live out in the desert than with a nagging, complaining wife.

Chapter 21.21:20: Wise people live in wealth and luxury, but stupid people spend their money as fast as they get it.

Chapter 21.21:21: Be kind and honest and you will live a long life; others will respect you and treat you fairly.

Chapter 21.21:22: A shrewd general can take a city defended by strong men, and destroy the walls they relied on.

Chapter 21.21:23: If you want to stay out of trouble, be careful what you say.

Chapter 21.21:24: Show me a conceited person and I will show you someone who is arrogant, proud, and inconsiderate.

Chapter 21.21:25: Lazy people who refuse to work are only killing themselves;

Chapter 21.21:26: all they do is think about what they would like to have. The righteous, however, can give, and give generously.

Chapter 21.21:27: The Lord hates it when wicked people offer him sacrifices, especially if they do it from evil motives.

Chapter 21.21:28: The testimony of a liar is not believed, but the word of someone who thinks matters through is accepted.

Chapter 21.21:29: Righteous people are sure of themselves; the wicked have to pretend as best they can.

Chapter 21.21:30: Human wisdom, brilliance, insight—they are of no help if the Lord is against you.

Chapter 21.21:31: You can get horses ready for battle, but it is the Lord who gives victory.

Chapter 22.22:1: If you have to choose between a good reputation and great wealth, choose a good reputation.

Chapter 22.22:2: The rich and the poor have this in common: the Lord made them both.

Chapter 22.22:3: Sensible people will see trouble coming and avoid it, but an unthinking person will walk right into it and regret it later.

Chapter 22.22:4: Obey the Lord, be humble, and you will get riches, honor, and a long life.

Chapter 22.22:5: If you love your life, stay away from the traps that catch the wicked along the way.

Chapter 22.22:6: Teach children how they should live, and they will remember it all their life.

Chapter 22.22:7: Poor people are slaves of the rich. Borrow money and you are the lender's slave.

Chapter 22.22:8: If you plant the seeds of injustice, disaster will spring up, and your oppression of others will end.

Chapter 22.22:9: Be generous and share your food with the poor. You will be blessed for it.

Chapter 22.22:10: Get rid of a conceited person, and then there will be no more arguments, quarreling, or name-calling.

Chapter 22.22:11: If you love purity of heart and graciousness of speech, the king will be your friend.

Chapter 22.22:12: The Lord sees to it that truth is kept safe by disproving the words of liars.

Chapter 22.22:13: Lazy people stay at home; they say a lion might get them if they go outside.

Chapter 22.22:14: Adultery is a trap—it catches those with whom the Lord is angry.

Chapter 22.22:15: Children just naturally do silly, careless things, but a good spanking will teach them how to behave.

Chapter 22.22:16: If you make gifts to rich people or oppress the poor to get rich, you will become poor yourself.

Chapter 22.22:17: Listen, and I will teach you what the wise have said. Study their teachings,

Chapter 22.22:18: and you will be glad if you remember them and can quote them.

Chapter 22.22:19: I want you to put your trust in the Lord; that is why I am going to tell them to you now.

Chapter 22.22:20: I have written down thirty sayings for you. They contain knowledge and good advice,

Chapter 22.22:21: and will teach you what the truth really is. Then when you are sent to find it out, you will bring back the right answer.

Chapter 22.22:22: Don't take advantage of the poor just because you can; don't take advantage of those who stand helpless in court.

Chapter 22.22:23: The Lord will argue their case for them and threaten the life of anyone who threatens theirs.

Chapter 22.22:24: Don't make friends with people who have hot, violent tempers.

Chapter 22.22:25: You might learn their habits and not be able to change.

Chapter 22.22:26: Don't promise to be responsible for someone else's debts.

Chapter 22.22:27: If you should be unable to pay, they will take away even your bed.

Chapter 22.22:28: Never move an old property line that your ancestors established.

Chapter 22.22:29: Show me someone who does a good job, and I will show you someone who is better than most and worthy of the company of kings.

Chapter 23.23:1: When you sit down to eat with someone important, keep in mind who he is.

Chapter 23.23:2: If you have a big appetite, restrain yourself.

Chapter 23.23:3: Don't be greedy for the fine food he serves; he may be trying to trick you.

Chapter 23.23:4: Be wise enough not to wear yourself out trying to get rich.

Chapter 23.23:5: Your money can be gone in a flash, as if it had grown wings and flown away like an eagle.

Chapter 23.23:6: Don't eat at the table of a stingy person or be greedy for the fine food he serves.

Chapter 23.23:7: Come on and have some more, he says, but he doesn't mean it. What he thinks is what he really is.

Chapter 23.23:8: You will vomit up what you have eaten, and all your flattery will be wasted.

Chapter 23.23:9: Don't try to talk sense to a fool; he can't appreciate it.

Chapter 23.23:10: Never move an old property line or take over land owned by orphans.

Chapter 23.23:11: The Lord is their powerful defender, and he will argue their case against you.

Chapter 23.23:12: Pay attention to your teacher and learn all you can.

Chapter 23.23:13: Don't hesitate to discipline children. A good spanking won't kill them.

Chapter 23.23:14: As a matter of fact, it may save their lives.

Chapter 23.23:15: My child, if you become wise, I will be very happy.

Chapter 23.23:16: I will be proud when I hear you speaking words of wisdom.

Chapter 23.23:17: Don't be envious of sinful people; let reverence for the Lord be the concern of your life.

Chapter 23.23:18: If it is, you have a bright future.

Chapter 23.23:19: Listen, my child, be wise and give serious thought to the way you live.

Chapter 23.23:20: Don't associate with people who drink too much wine or stuff themselves with food.

Chapter 23.23:21: Drunkards and gluttons will be reduced to poverty. If all you do is eat and sleep, you will soon be wearing rags.

Chapter 23.23:22: Listen to your father; without him you would not exist. When your mother is old, show her your appreciation.

Chapter 23.23:23: Truth, wisdom, learning, and good sense—these are worth paying for, but too valuable for you to sell.

Chapter 4.4:1: It is better to have virtue, even if it means having no children. Your virtue will be recognized by other people and by God, and you will be remembered for it forever.

Chapter 4.4:3: No matter how many children are born of a forbidden union, none of them will ever amount to anything. They are illegitimate; they can never lay a firm foundation for themselves, never take deep root.

Chapter 4.4:9: Wisdom and righteousness are signs of the maturity that should come with old age.

Chapter 4.4:19: God will throw them to the ground and make them speechless. Like buildings shaken from their foundations, they will be reduced to piles of ruins. They will be in torment. People will soon forget all about them.

Chapter 7.7:20: He has taught me about the nature of living creatures, the behavior of wild animals, the force of the winds, the reasoning powers of human beings, the different kinds of plants, and the use of their roots as medicine.

Chapter 7.7:21: I learned things that were well known and things that had never been known before,

Chapter 7.7:26: She is a reflection of eternal light, a perfect mirror of God's activity and goodness.

Chapter 7.7:28: There is nothing that God loves more than people who are at home with Wisdom.

Chapter 7.7:29: Wisdom is more beautiful than the sun and all the constellations. She is better than light itself,

Chapter 4.4:19: But if you go astray, she will abandon you and let you go to your own ruin.

Chapter 4.4:29: Don't be quick to speak or lazy and negligent in your work.

Chapter 5.5:1: Don't rely on money to make you independent.

Chapter 6.6:1: and do not be an enemy when you should be a friend. A bad reputation brings you the disgrace that lying sinners deserve.

Chapter 7.7:1: If you do no wrong, no wrong will ever come to you.

Chapter 7.7:3: Do not plow the ground to plant seeds of injustice; you may reap a bigger harvest than you expect.

Chapter 7.7:4: Don't ask the Lord for a place of honor or ask the king for an important position.

Chapter 7.7:5: Don't try to convince the Lord that you are righteous or make a show of your wisdom before the king.

Chapter 7.7:8: Don't commit the same sin twice. The punishment you get the first time ought to be enough.

Chapter 7.7:9: Don't think that God Most High is going to take into account how very generous you are and so accept any offering you decide to make.

Chapter 7.7:10: Never get tired of praying, and never miss a chance to give to the poor.

Chapter 7.7:11: Don't laugh at someone who has been humiliated. It is the Lord who humbles a person, but the Lord also raises him up again.

Chapter 7.7:12: Don't think up lies to tell about your friends.

Chapter 7.7:13: Don't tell lies at all. It never does any good.

Chapter 7.7:17: Be very humble, because the decay of death awaits us all.

Chapter 7.7:21: Show the same love to wise servants that you would show to yourself, and let them have their freedom.

Chapter 7.7:22: Take good care of any animals you own. If they make money for you, keep them.

Chapter 7.7:24: If you have daughters, keep them virtuous, and don't be too indulgent with them.

Chapter 7.7:25: When you give your daughter in marriage, you have finished a great task, but give her to a sensible man.

Chapter 7.7:26: If you have a good wife, do not divorce her, but do not trust yourself to someone you don't love.

Chapter 7.7:27: Honor your father with all your heart, and never forget how your mother suffered when you were born.

Chapter 7.7:28: Remember that you owe your life to them. How can you ever repay them for all they have done for you?

Chapter 7.7:29: Fear the Lord with all your heart, and have respect for his priests.

Chapter 7.7:30: Love your Creator with all your strength, and give his ministers your support.

Chapter 7.7:31: Honor the Lord and respect the priests. Supply them with what you have been commanded to give: the first produce, the offering for sin, the shoulder of the sacrificial animal—all the required sacrifices and offerings.

Chapter 7.7:33: Be generous to every living soul, and be gracious to the memory of the dead.

Chapter 7.7:34: Show sympathy to those who have lost a loved one, and mourn with them.

Chapter 7.7:35: Do not hesitate to visit the sick. You will be loved for things like these.

Chapter 7.7:36: Whatever you do, remember that some day you must die. As long as you keep this in mind, you will never sin.

Chapter 8.8:1: Do not challenge a person who has influence; you may fall into his power.

Chapter 8.8:18: You should not do anything in front of a stranger that should be kept secret. There is no way of knowing what will happen if you do.

Chapter 9.9:16: Choose righteous people for your dinner companions. Your chief pride should be your fear of the Lord.

Chapter 13.13:17: A sinner has no more in common with a devout person than a wolf has with a lamb.
