Chapter 1.1:31: Just as straw is set on fire by a spark, so powerful people will be destroyed by their own evil deeds, and no one will be able to stop the destruction.

Chapter 3.3:1: Now the Lord, the Almighty Lord, is about to take away from Jerusalem and Judah everything and everyone that the people depend on. He is going to take away their food and their water,

Chapter 3.3:2: their heroes and their soldiers, their judges and their prophets, their fortunetellers and their statesmen,

Chapter 3.3:3: their military and civilian leaders, their politicians and everyone who uses magic to control events.

Chapter 3.3:4: The Lord will let the people be governed by immature boys.

Chapter 3.3:5: Everyone will take advantage of everyone else. Young people will not respect their elders, and worthless people will not respect their superiors.

Chapter 3.3:6: A time will come when the members of a clan will choose one of their number and say to him, You at least have something to wear, so be our leader in this time of trouble.

Chapter 3.3:7: But he will answer, Not me! I can't help you. I don't have any food or clothes either. Don't make me your leader!

Chapter 3.3:8: Yes, Jerusalem is doomed! Judah is collapsing! Everything they say and do is against the Lord; they openly insult God himself.

Chapter 3.3:9: Their prejudices will be held against them. They sin as openly as the people of Sodom did. They are doomed, and they have brought it on themselves.

Chapter 3.3:10: The righteous will be happy, and things will go well for them. They will get to enjoy what they have worked for.

Chapter 3.3:11: But evil people are doomed; what they have done to others will now be done to them.

Chapter 3.3:12: Moneylenders oppress my people, and their creditors cheat them. My people, your leaders are misleading you, so that you do not know which way to turn.

Chapter 3.3:13: The Lord is ready to state his case; he is ready to judge his people.

Chapter 3.3:14: The Lord is bringing the elders and leaders of his people to judgment. He makes this accusation: You have plundered vineyards, and your houses are full of what you have taken from the poor.

Chapter 3.3:15: You have no right to crush my people and take advantage of the poor. I, the Sovereign Lord Almighty, have spoken.

Chapter 3.3:16: The Lord said, Look how proud the women of Jerusalem are! They walk along with their noses in the air. They are always flirting. They take dainty little steps, and the bracelets on their ankles jingle.

Chapter 3.3:17: But I will punish them—I will shave their heads and leave them bald.

Chapter 3.3:18: A day is coming when the Lord will take away from the women of Jerusalem everything they are so proud of—the ornaments they wear on their ankles, on their heads, on their necks,

Chapter 3.3:19: and on their wrists. He will take away their veils

Chapter 3.3:20: and their hats; the magic charms they wear on their arms and at their waists;

Chapter 3.3:21: the rings they wear on their fingers and in their noses;

Chapter 3.3:22: all their fine robes, gowns, cloaks, and purses;

Chapter 3.3:23: their revealing garments, their linen handkerchiefs, and the scarves and long veils they wear on their heads.

Chapter 3.3:24: Instead of using perfumes, they will stink; instead of fine belts, they will wear coarse ropes; instead of having beautiful hair, they will be bald; instead of fine clothes, they will be dressed in rags; their beauty will be turned to shame!

Chapter 3.3:25: The men of the city, yes, even the strongest men, will be killed in war.

Chapter 3.3:26: The city gates will mourn and cry, and the city itself will be like a woman sitting on the ground, stripped naked.

Chapter 4.4:1: When that time comes, seven women will grab hold of one man and say, We can feed and clothe ourselves, but please let us say you are our husband, so that we won't have to endure the shame of being unmarried.

Chapter 4.4:2: The time is coming when the Lord will make every plant and tree in the land grow large and beautiful. All the people of Israel who survive will take delight and pride in the crops that the land produces.

Chapter 4.4:3: Everyone who is left in Jerusalem, whom God has chosen for survival, will be called holy.

Chapter 4.4:4: By his power the Lord will judge and purify the nation and wash away the guilt of Jerusalem and the blood that has been shed there.

Chapter 4.4:5: Then over Mount Zion and over all who are gathered there, the Lord will send a cloud in the daytime and smoke and a bright flame at night. God's glory will cover and protect the whole city.

Chapter 4.4:6: His glory will shade the city from the heat of the day and make it a place of safety, sheltered from the rain and storm.

Chapter 6.6:1: In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord. He was sitting on his throne, high and exalted, and his robe filled the whole Temple.

Chapter 6.6:2: Around him flaming creatures were standing, each of which had six wings. Each creature covered its face with two wings, and its body with two, and used the other two for flying.

Chapter 6.6:3: They were calling out to each other: Holy, holy, holy! The Lord Almighty is holy! His glory fills the world.

Chapter 6.6:4: The sound of their voices made the foundation of the Temple shake, and the Temple itself became filled with smoke.

Chapter 6.6:5: I said, There is no hope for me! I am doomed because every word that passes my lips is sinful, and I live among a people whose every word is sinful. And yet, with my own eyes I have seen the King, the Lord Almighty.

Chapter 6.6:6: Then one of the creatures flew down to me, carrying a burning coal that he had taken from the altar with a pair of tongs.

Chapter 6.6:7: He touched my lips with the burning coal and said, This has touched your lips, and now your guilt is gone, and your sins are forgiven.

Chapter 6.6:8: Then I heard the Lord say, Whom shall I send? Who will be our messenger? I answered, I will go! Send me!

Chapter 6.6:9: So he told me to go and give the people this message: No matter how much you listen, you will not understand. No matter how much you look, you will not know what is happening.

Chapter 6.6:10: Then he said to me, Make the minds of these people dull, their ears deaf, and their eyes blind, so that they cannot see or hear or understand. If they did, they might turn to me and be healed.

Chapter 6.6:11: I asked, How long will it be like this, Lord? He answered, Until the cities are ruined and empty—until the houses are uninhabited—until the land itself is a desolate wasteland.

Chapter 6.6:12: I will send the people far away and make the whole land desolate.

Chapter 6.6:13: Even if one person out of ten remains in the land, he too will be destroyed; he will be like the stump of an oak tree that has been cut down. The stump represents a new beginning for God's people.

Chapter 7.7:1: When King Ahaz, the son of Jotham and grandson of Uzziah, ruled Judah, war broke out. Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah son of Remaliah, king of Israel, attacked Jerusalem, but were unable to capture it.

Chapter 7.7:2: When word reached the king of Judah that the armies of Syria were already in the territory of Israel, he and all his people were so terrified that they trembled like trees shaking in the wind.

Chapter 7.7:3: The Lord said to Isaiah, Take your son Shear Jashub, and go to meet King Ahaz. You will find him on the road where the cloth makers work, at the end of the ditch that brings water from the upper pool.

Chapter 7.7:4: Tell him to keep alert, to stay calm, and not to be frightened or disturbed. The anger of King Rezin and his Syrians and of King Pekah is no more dangerous than the smoke from two smoldering sticks of wood.

Chapter 7.7:5: Syria, together with Israel and its king, has made a plot.

Chapter 7.7:6: They intend to invade Judah, terrify the people into joining their side, and then put Tabeel's son on the throne.

Chapter 7.7:7: But I, the Lord, declare that this will never happen.

Chapter 7.7:8: Why? Because Syria is no stronger than Damascus, its capital city, and Damascus is no stronger than King Rezin. As for Israel, within sixty-five years it will be too shattered to survive as a nation.

Chapter 7.7:9: Israel is no stronger than Samaria, its capital city, and Samaria is no stronger than King Pekah. If your faith is not enduring, you will not endure.

Chapter 7.7:10: The Lord sent another message to Ahaz:

Chapter 7.7:11: Ask the Lord your God to give you a sign. It can be from deep in the world of the dead or from high up in heaven.

Chapter 7.7:12: Ahaz answered, I will not ask for a sign. I refuse to put the Lord to the test.

Chapter 7.7:13: To that Isaiah replied, Listen, now, descendants of King David. It's bad enough for you to wear out the patience of people—do you have to wear out God's patience too?

Chapter 7.7:14: Well then, the Lord himself will give you a sign: a young woman who is pregnant will have a son and will name him Immanuel.

Chapter 7.7:15: By the time he is old enough to make his own decisions, people will be drinking milk and eating honey.

Chapter 7.7:16: Even before that time comes, the lands of those two kings who terrify you will be deserted.

Chapter 7.7:17: The Lord is going to bring on you, on your people, and on the whole royal family, days of trouble worse than any that have come since the kingdom of Israel separated from Judah—he is going to bring the king of Assyria.

Chapter 7.7:18: When that time comes, the Lord will whistle as a signal for the Egyptians to come like flies from the farthest branches of the Nile, and for the Assyrians to come from their land like bees.

Chapter 7.7:19: They will swarm in the rugged valleys and in the caves in the rocks, and they will cover every thorn bush and every pasture.

Chapter 7.7:20: When that time comes, the Lord will hire a barber from across the Euphrates—the emperor of Assyria!—and he will shave off your beards and the hair on your heads and your bodies.

Chapter 7.7:21: When that time comes, even if a farmer has been able to save only one young cow and two goats,

Chapter 7.7:22: they will give so much milk that he will have all he needs. Yes, the few survivors left in the land will have milk and honey to eat.

Chapter 7.7:23: When that time comes, the fine vineyards, each with a thousand vines and each worth a thousand pieces of silver, will be overgrown with thorn bushes and briers.

Chapter 7.7:24: People will go hunting there with bows and arrows. Yes, the whole country will be full of briers and thorn bushes.

Chapter 7.7:25: All the hills where crops were once planted will be so overgrown with thorns that no one will go there. It will be a place where cattle and sheep graze.

Chapter 8.8:1: The Lord said to me, Take a large piece of writing material and write on it in large letters: Quick Loot, Fast Plunder.

Chapter 8.8:2: Get two reliable men, the priest Uriah and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah, to serve as witnesses.

Chapter 8.8:3: Some time later my wife became pregnant. When our son was born, the Lord said to me, Name him Quick-Loot-Fast-Plunder.

Chapter 8.8:4: Before the boy is old enough to say Mamma and Daddy, all the wealth of Damascus and all the loot of Samaria will be carried off by the king of Assyria.

Chapter 8.8:5: The Lord spoke to me again.

Chapter 8.8:6: He said, Because these people have rejected the quiet waters of Shiloah Brook and tremble before King Rezin and King Pekah,

Chapter 8.8:7: I, the Lord, will bring the emperor of Assyria and all his forces to attack Judah. They will advance like the flood waters of the Euphrates River, overflowing all its banks.

Chapter 8.8:8: They will sweep through Judah in a flood, rising shoulder high and covering everything. God is with us! His outspread wings protect the land.

Chapter 8.8:9: Gather together in fear, you nations! Listen, you distant parts of the earth. Get ready to fight, but be afraid! Yes, get ready, but be afraid!

Chapter 8.8:10: Make your plans! But they will never succeed. Talk all you want to! But it is all useless, because God is with us.

Chapter 8.8:11: With his great power the Lord warned me not to follow the road which the people were following. He said,

Chapter 8.8:12: Do not join in the schemes of the people and do not be afraid of the things that they fear.

Chapter 8.8:13: Remember that I, the Lord Almighty, am holy; I am the one you must fear.

Chapter 8.8:14: Because of my awesome holiness I am like a stone that people stumble over; I am like a trap that will catch the people of the kingdoms of Judah and Israel and the people of Jerusalem.

Chapter 8.8:15: Many will stumble; they will fall and be crushed. They will be caught in a trap.

Chapter 8.8:16: You, my disciples, are to guard and preserve the messages that God has given me.

Chapter 8.8:17: The Lord has hidden himself from his people, but I trust him and place my hope in him.

Chapter 8.8:18: Here I am with the children the Lord has given me. The Lord Almighty, whose throne is on Mount Zion, has sent us as living messages to the people of Israel.

Chapter 8.8:19: But people will tell you to ask for messages from fortunetellers and mediums, who chirp and mutter. They will say, After all, people should ask for messages from the spirits and consult the dead on behalf of the living.

Chapter 8.8:20: You are to answer them, Listen to what the Lord is teaching you! Don't listen to mediums—what they tell you cannot keep trouble away.

Chapter 8.8:21: The people will wander through the land, discouraged and hungry. In their hunger and their anger they will curse their king and their God. They may look up to the sky

Chapter 8.8:22: or stare at the ground, but they will see nothing but trouble and darkness, terrifying darkness into which they are being driven.

Chapter 10.10:1: You are doomed! You make unjust laws that oppress my people.

Chapter 10.10:2: That is how you keep the poor from having their rights and from getting justice. That is how you take the property that belongs to widows and orphans.

Chapter 10.10:3: What will you do when God punishes you? What will you do when he brings disaster on you from a distant country? Where will you run to find help? Where will you hide your wealth?

Chapter 10.10:4: You will be killed in battle or dragged off as prisoners. Yet even so the Lord's anger will not be ended; his hand will still be stretched out to punish.

Chapter 10.10:5: The Lord said, Assyria! I use Assyria like a club to punish those with whom I am angry.

Chapter 10.10:6: I sent Assyria to attack a godless nation, people who have made me angry. I sent them to loot and steal and trample the people like dirt in the streets.

Chapter 10.10:7: But the Assyrian emperor has his own violent plans in mind. He is determined to destroy many nations.

Chapter 10.10:8: He boasts, Every one of my commanders is a king!

Chapter 10.10:9: I conquered the cities of Calno and Carchemish, the cities of Hamath and Arpad. I conquered Samaria and Damascus.

Chapter 10.10:10: I reached out to punish those kingdoms that worship idols, idols more numerous than those of Jerusalem and Samaria.

Chapter 10.10:11: I have destroyed Samaria and all its idols, and I will do the same to Jerusalem and the images that are worshiped there.

Chapter 10.10:12: But the Lord says, When I finish what I am doing on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, I will punish the emperor of Assyria for all his boasting and all his pride.

Chapter 10.10:13: The emperor of Assyria boasts, I have done it all myself. I am strong and wise and clever. I wiped out the boundaries between nations and took the supplies they had stored. Like a bull I have trampled the people who live there.

Chapter 10.10:14: The nations of the world were like a bird's nest, and I gathered their wealth as easily as gathering eggs. Not a wing fluttered to scare me off; no beak opened to scream at me!

Chapter 10.10:15: But the Lord says, Can an ax claim to be greater than the one who uses it? Is a saw more important than the one who saws with it? A club doesn't lift up a person; a person lifts up a club.

Chapter 10.10:16: The Lord Almighty is going to send disease to punish those who are now well-fed. In their bodies there will be a fire that burns and burns.

Chapter 10.10:17: God, the light of Israel, will become a fire. Israel's holy God will become a flame, which in a single day will burn up everything, even the thorns and thistles.

Chapter 10.10:18: The rich forests and farmlands will be totally destroyed, in the same way that a fatal sickness destroys someone.

Chapter 10.10:19: There will be so few trees left that even a child will be able to count them.

Chapter 10.10:20: A time is coming when the people of Israel who have survived will not rely any more on the nation that almost destroyed them. They will truly put their trust in the Lord, Israel's holy God.

Chapter 10.10:21: A few of the people of Israel will come back to their mighty God.

Chapter 10.10:22: Even though now there are as many people of Israel as there are grains of sand by the sea, only a few will come back. Destruction is in store for the people, and it is fully deserved.

Chapter 10.10:23: Yes, throughout the whole country the Sovereign Lord Almighty will bring destruction, as he said he would.

Chapter 10.10:24: The Sovereign Lord Almighty says to his people who live in Zion, Do not be afraid of the Assyrians, even though they oppress you as the Egyptians used to do.

Chapter 10.10:25: In only a little while I will finish punishing you, and then I will destroy them.

Chapter 10.10:26: I, the Lord Almighty, will beat them with my whip as I did the people of Midian at Oreb Rock. I will punish Assyria as I punished Egypt.

Chapter 10.10:27: When that time comes, I will free you from the power of Assyria, and their yoke will no longer be a burden on your shoulders.

Chapter 10.10:28: The enemy army has captured the city of Ai! They have passed through Migron! They left their supplies at Michmash!

Chapter 10.10:29: They have crossed the pass and are spending the night at Geba! The people in the town of Ramah are terrified, and the people in King Saul's hometown of Gibeah have run away.

Chapter 10.10:30: Shout, people of Gallim! Listen, people of Laishah! Answer, people of Anathoth!

Chapter 10.10:31: The people of Madmenah and Gebim are running for their lives.

Chapter 10.10:32: Today the enemy are in the town of Nob, and there they are shaking their fists at Mount Zion, at the city of Jerusalem.

Chapter 10.10:33: The Lord Almighty will bring them crashing down like branches cut off a tree. The proudest and highest of them will be cut down and humiliated.

Chapter 10.10:34: The Lord will cut them down as trees in the heart of the forest are cut down with an ax, as even the finest trees of Lebanon fall!

Chapter 13.13:1: This is a message about Babylon, which Isaiah son of Amoz received from God.

Chapter 13.13:2: On the top of a barren hill raise the battle flag! Shout to the soldiers and raise your arm as the signal for them to attack the gates of the proud city.

Chapter 13.13:3: The Lord has called out his proud and confident soldiers to fight a holy war and punish those he is angry with.

Chapter 13.13:4: Listen to the noise on the mountains—the sound of a great crowd of people, the sound of nations and kingdoms gathering. The Lord of Armies is preparing his troops for battle.

Chapter 13.13:5: They are coming from far-off countries at the ends of the earth. In his anger the Lord is coming to devastate the whole country.

Chapter 13.13:6: Howl in pain! The day of the Lord is near, the day when the Almighty brings destruction.

Chapter 13.13:7: Everyone's hands will hang limp, and everyone's courage will fail.

Chapter 13.13:8: They will all be terrified and overcome with pain, like the pain of a woman in labor. They will look at each other in fear, and their faces will burn with shame.

Chapter 13.13:9: The day of the Lord is coming—that cruel day of his fierce anger and fury. The earth will be made a wilderness, and every sinner will be destroyed.

Chapter 13.13:10: Every star and every constellation will stop shining, the sun will be dark when it rises, and the moon will give no light.

Chapter 13.13:11: The Lord says, I will bring disaster on the earth and punish all wicked people for their sins. I will humble everyone who is proud and punish everyone who is arrogant and cruel.

Chapter 13.13:12: Those who survive will be scarcer than gold.

Chapter 13.13:13: I will make the heavens tremble, and the earth will be shaken out of its place on that day when I, the Lord Almighty, show my anger.

Chapter 13.13:14: The foreigners living in Babylon will run away to their homelands, scattering like deer escaping from hunters, like sheep without a shepherd.

Chapter 13.13:15: Anyone who is caught will be stabbed to death.

Chapter 13.13:16: While they look on helplessly, their babies will be battered to death, their houses will be looted, and their wives will be raped.

Chapter 13.13:17: The Lord says, I am stirring up the Medes to attack Babylon. They care nothing for silver and are not tempted by gold.

Chapter 13.13:18: With their bows and arrows they will kill the young men. They will show no mercy to babies and take no pity on children.

Chapter 13.13:19: Babylonia is the most beautiful kingdom of all; it is the pride of its people. But I, the Lord, will overthrow Babylon as I did Sodom and Gomorrah!

Chapter 13.13:20: No one will ever live there again. No wandering Arab will ever pitch a tent there, and no shepherd will ever pasture a flock there.

Chapter 13.13:21: It will be a place where desert animals live and where owls build their nests. Ostriches will live there, and wild goats will prance through the ruins.

Chapter 13.13:22: The towers and palaces will echo with the cries of hyenas and jackals. Babylon's time has come! Her days are almost over.

Chapter 14.14:1: The Lord will once again be merciful to his people Israel and choose them as his own. He will let them live in their own land again, and foreigners will come and live there with them.

Chapter 14.14:2: Many nations will help the people of Israel return to the land which the Lord gave them, and there the nations will serve Israel as slaves. Those who once captured Israel will now be captured by Israel, and the people of Israel will rule over those who once oppressed them.

Chapter 14.14:3: The Lord will give the people of Israel relief from their pain and suffering and from the hard work they were forced to do.

Chapter 14.14:4: When he does this, they are to mock the king of Babylon and say: The cruel king has fallen! He will never oppress anyone again!

Chapter 14.14:5: The Lord has ended the power of the evil rulers

Chapter 14.14:6: who angrily oppressed the peoples and never stopped persecuting the nations they had conquered.

Chapter 14.14:7: Now at last the whole world enjoys rest and peace, and everyone sings for joy.

Chapter 14.14:8: The cypress trees and the cedars of Lebanon rejoice over the fallen king, because there is no one to cut them down, now that he is gone!

Chapter 14.14:9: The world of the dead is getting ready to welcome the king of Babylon. The ghosts of those who were powerful on earth are stirring about. The ghosts of kings are rising from their thrones.

Chapter 14.14:10: They all call out to him, Now you are as weak as we are! You are one of us!

Chapter 14.14:11: You used to be honored with the music of harps, but now here you are in the world of the dead. You lie on a bed of maggots and are covered with a blanket of worms.

Chapter 14.14:12: King of Babylon, bright morning star, you have fallen from heaven! In the past you conquered nations, but now you have been thrown to the ground.

Chapter 14.14:13: You were determined to climb up to heaven and to place your throne above the highest stars. You thought you would sit like a king on that mountain in the north where the gods assemble.

Chapter 14.14:14: You said you would climb to the tops of the clouds and be like the Almighty.

Chapter 14.14:15: But instead, you have been brought down to the deepest part of the world of the dead.

Chapter 14.14:16: The dead will stare and gape at you. They will ask, Is this the man who shook the earth and made kingdoms tremble?

Chapter 14.14:17: Is this the man who destroyed cities and turned the world into a desert? Is this the man who never freed his prisoners or let them go home?

Chapter 14.14:18: All the kings of the earth lie in their magnificent tombs,

Chapter 14.14:19: but you have no tomb, and your corpse is thrown out to rot. It is covered by the bodies of soldiers killed in battle, thrown with them into a rocky pit, and trampled down.

Chapter 14.14:20: Because you ruined your country and killed your own people, you will not be buried like other kings. None of your evil family will survive.

Chapter 14.14:21: Let the slaughter begin! The sons of this king will die because of their ancestors' sins. None of them will ever rule the earth or cover it with cities.

Chapter 14.14:22: The Lord Almighty says, I will attack Babylon and bring it to ruin. I will leave nothing—no children, no survivors at all. I, the Lord, have spoken.

Chapter 14.14:23: I will turn Babylon into a marsh, and owls will live there. I will sweep Babylon with a broom that will sweep everything away. I, the Lord Almighty, have spoken.

Chapter 14.14:24: The Lord Almighty has sworn an oath: What I have planned will happen. What I have determined to do will be done.

Chapter 14.14:25: I will destroy the Assyrians in my land of Israel and trample them on my mountains. I will free my people from the Assyrian yoke and from the burdens they have had to bear.

Chapter 14.14:26: This is my plan for the world, and my arm is stretched out to punish the nations.

Chapter 14.14:27: The Lord Almighty is determined to do this; he has stretched out his arm to punish, and no one can stop him.

Chapter 14.14:28: This is a message that was proclaimed in the year that King Ahaz died.

Chapter 14.14:29: People of Philistia, the rod that beat you is broken, but you have no reason to be glad. When one snake dies, a worse one comes in its place. A snake's egg hatches a flying dragon.

Chapter 14.14:30: The Lord will be a shepherd to the poor of his people and will let them live in safety. But he will send a terrible famine on you Philistines, and it will not leave any of you alive.

Chapter 14.14:31: Howl and cry for help, all you Philistine cities! Be terrified, all of you! A cloud of dust is coming from the north—it is an army with no cowards in its ranks.

Chapter 14.14:32: How shall we answer the messengers that come to us from Philistia? We will tell them that the Lord has established Zion and that his suffering people will find safety there.

Chapter 15.15:1: This is a message about Moab. The cities of Ar and Kir are destroyed in a single night, and silence covers the land of Moab.

Chapter 15.15:2: The people of Dibon climb the hill to weep at the shrine. The people of Moab wail in grief over the cities of Nebo and Medeba; they have shaved their heads and their beards in grief.

Chapter 15.15:3: The people in the streets are dressed in sackcloth; in the city squares and on the rooftops people mourn and cry.

Chapter 15.15:4: The people of Heshbon and Elealeh cry out, and their cry can be heard as far away as Jahaz. Even the soldiers tremble; their courage is gone.

Chapter 15.15:5: My heart cries out for Moab! The people have fled to the town of Zoar, and to Eglath Shelishiyah. Some climb the road to Luhith, weeping as they go; some escape to Horonaim, grieving loudly.

Chapter 15.15:7: The people go across the Valley of Willows, trying to escape with all their possessions.

Chapter 15.15:8: Everywhere at Moab's borders the sound of crying is heard. It is heard at the towns of Eglaim and Beerelim.

Chapter 16.16:1: From the city of Sela in the desert the people of Moab send a lamb as a present to the one who rules in Jerusalem.

Chapter 16.16:2: They wait on the banks of the Arnon River and move aimlessly back and forth, like birds driven from their nest.

Chapter 16.16:3: They say to the people of Judah, Tell us what to do. Protect us like a tree that casts a cool shadow in the heat of noon, and let us rest in your shade. We are refugees; hide us where no one can find us.

Chapter 16.16:4: Let us stay in your land. Protect us from those who want to destroy us. Oppression and destruction will end, and those who are devastating the country will be gone.

Chapter 16.16:5: Then one of David's descendants will be king, and he will rule the people with faithfulness and love. He will be quick to do what is right, and he will see that justice is done.

Chapter 16.16:6: The people of Judah say, We have heard how proud the people of Moab are. We know that they are arrogant and conceited, but their boasts are empty.

Chapter 16.16:8: The farms near Heshbon and the vineyards of Sibmah are destroyed—those vineyards whose wine used to make the rulers of the nations drunk. At one time the vines spread as far as the city of Jazer, and eastward into the desert, and westward to the other side of the Dead Sea.

Chapter 16.16:9: Now I weep for Sibmah's vines as I weep for Jazer. My tears fall for Heshbon and Elealeh, because there is no harvest to make the people glad.

Chapter 16.16:10: No one is happy now in the fertile fields. No one shouts or sings in the vineyards. No one tramples grapes to make wine; the shouts of joy are ended.

Chapter 16.16:11: I groan with sadness for Moab, with grief for Kir Heres.

Chapter 16.16:12: The people of Moab wear themselves out going to their mountain shrines and to their temples to pray, but it will do them no good.

Chapter 16.16:13: That is the message the Lord gave earlier about Moab.

Chapter 58.58:3: The people ask, Why should we fast if the Lord never notices? Why should we go without food if he pays no attention? The Lord says to them, The truth is that at the same time you fast, you pursue your own interests and oppress your workers.

Chapter 58.58:4: Your fasting makes you violent, and you quarrel and fight. Do you think this kind of fasting will make me listen to your prayers?

Chapter 58.58:5: When you fast, you make yourselves suffer; you bow your heads low like a blade of grass and spread out sackcloth and ashes to lie on. Is that what you call fasting? Do you think I will be pleased with that?

Chapter 58.58:6: The kind of fasting I want is this: Remove the chains of oppression and the yoke of injustice, and let the oppressed go free.

Chapter 58.58:7: Share your food with the hungry and open your homes to the homeless poor. Give clothes to those who have nothing to wear, and do not refuse to help your own relatives.

Chapter 58.58:8: Then my favor will shine on you like the morning sun, and your wounds will be quickly healed. I will always be with you to save you; my presence will protect you on every side.

Chapter 58.58:9: When you pray, I will answer you. When you call to me, I will respond. If you put an end to oppression, to every gesture of contempt, and to every evil word;

Chapter 58.58:10: if you give food to the hungry and satisfy those who are in need, then the darkness around you will turn to the brightness of noon.

Chapter 58.58:11: And I will always guide you and satisfy you with good things. I will keep you strong and well. You will be like a garden that has plenty of water, like a spring of water that never goes dry.

Chapter 58.58:12: Your people will rebuild what has long been in ruins, building again on the old foundations. You will be known as the people who rebuilt the walls, who restored the ruined houses.

Chapter 58.58:13: The Lord says, If you treat the Sabbath as sacred and do not pursue your own interests on that day; if you value my holy day and honor it by not traveling, working, or talking idly on that day,

Chapter 59.59:3: You are guilty of lying, violence, and murder.

Chapter 59.59:4: You go to court, but you do not have justice on your side. You depend on lies to win your case. You carry out your plans to hurt others.

Chapter 59.59:5: The evil plots you make are as deadly as the eggs of a poisonous snake. Crush an egg, out comes a snake! But your plots will do you no good—they are as useless as clothing made of cobwebs!

Chapter 59.59:6: The evil plots you make are as deadly as the eggs of a poisonous snake. Crush an egg, out comes a snake! But your plots will do you no good—they are as useless as clothing made of cobwebs!

Chapter 59.59:12: Lord, our crimes against you are many. Our sins accuse us. We are well aware of them all.

Chapter 59.59:14: Justice is driven away, and right cannot come near. Truth stumbles in the public square, and honesty finds no place there.

Chapter 59.59:16: He is astonished to see that there is no one to help the oppressed. So he will use his own power to rescue them and to win the victory.

Chapter 59.59:17: He will wear justice like a coat of armor and saving power like a helmet. He will clothe himself with the strong desire to set things right and to punish and avenge the wrongs that people suffer.

Chapter 59.59:18: He will punish his enemies according to what they have done, even those who live in distant lands.

Chapter 59.59:19: From east to west everyone will fear him and his great power. He will come like a rushing river, like a strong wind.

Chapter 59.59:20: The Lord says to his people, I will come to Jerusalem to defend you and to save all of you that turn from your sins.

Chapter 59.59:21: And I make a covenant with you: I have given you my power and my teachings to be yours forever, and from now on you are to obey me and teach your children and your descendants to obey me for all time to come.

Chapter 60.60:1: Arise, Jerusalem, and shine like the sun; The glory of the Lord is shining on you!

Chapter 60.60:18: The sounds of violence will be heard no more; Destruction will not shatter your country again. I will protect and defend you like a wall; You will praise me because I have saved you.

Chapter 60.60:19: No longer will the sun be your light by day Or the moon be your light by night; I, the Lord, will be your eternal light; The light of my glory will shine on you.

Chapter 60.60:20: Your days of grief will come to an end. I, the Lord, will be your eternal light, More lasting than the sun and moon.

Chapter 60.60:21: Your people will all do what is right, And will possess the land forever. I planted them, I made them, To reveal my greatness to all.

Chapter 60.60:22: Even your smallest and humblest family Will become as great as a powerful nation. When the right time comes, I will make this happen quickly. I am the Lord!

Chapter 1.1:1: This book is the account of what was said by Jeremiah son of Hilkiah, one of the priests of the town of Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin.

Chapter 1.1:2: The Lord spoke to Jeremiah in the thirteenth year that Josiah son of Amon was king of Judah,

Chapter 1.1:3: and he spoke to him again when Josiah's son Jehoiakim was king. After that, the Lord spoke to him many times, until the eleventh year of the reign of Zedekiah son of Josiah. In the fifth month of that year the people of Jerusalem were taken into exile.

Chapter 1.1:4: The Lord said to me,

Chapter 1.1:5: I chose you before I gave you life, and before you were born I selected you to be a prophet to the nations.

Chapter 1.1:6: I answered, Sovereign Lord, I don't know how to speak; I am too young.

Chapter 1.1:7: But the Lord said to me, Do not say that you are too young, but go to the people I send you to, and tell them everything I command you to say.

Chapter 1.1:8: Do not be afraid of them, for I will be with you to protect you. I, the Lord, have spoken!

Chapter 1.1:9: Then the Lord reached out, touched my lips, and said to me, Listen, I am giving you the words you must speak.

Chapter 1.1:10: Today I give you authority over nations and kingdoms to uproot and to pull down, to destroy and to overthrow, to build and to plant.

Chapter 1.1:11: The Lord asked me, Jeremiah, what do you see? I answered, A branch of an almond tree.

Chapter 1.1:12: You are right, the Lord said, and I am watching to see that my words come true.

Chapter 1.1:13: Then the Lord spoke to me again. What else do you see? he asked. I answered, I see a pot boiling in the north, and it is about to tip over this way.

Chapter 1.1:14: He said to me, Destruction will boil over from the north on all who live in this land,

Chapter 1.1:15: because I am calling all the nations in the north to come. Their kings will set up their thrones at the gates of Jerusalem and around its walls and also around the other cities of Judah.

Chapter 1.1:16: I will punish my people because they have sinned; they have abandoned me, have offered sacrifices to other gods, and have made idols and worshiped them.

Chapter 1.1:17: Get ready, Jeremiah; go and tell them everything I command you to say. Do not be afraid of them now, or I will make you even more afraid when you are with them.

Chapter 1.1:19: 18-Listen, Jeremiah! Everyone in this land—the kings of Judah, the officials, the priests, and the people—will be against you. But today I am giving you the strength to resist them; you will be like a fortified city, an iron pillar, and a bronze wall. They will not defeat you, for I will be with you to protect you. I, the Lord, have spoken.

Chapter 3.3:13: At that, the king flew into a rage and ordered the three men to be brought before him.

Chapter 3.3:19: Then Nebuchadnezzar lost his temper, and his face turned red with anger at Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. So he ordered the furnace to be heated seven times hotter than usual.

Chapter 3.3:23: Then Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, still tied up, fell into the heart of the blazing fire.

Chapter 5.5:1: One night King Belshazzar invited a thousand noblemen to a great banquet, and they drank wine together.

Chapter 5.5:12: He has unusual ability and is wise and skillful in interpreting dreams, solving riddles, and explaining mysteries; so send for this man Daniel, whom the king named Belteshazzar, and he will tell you what all this means.

Chapter 5.5:14: I have heard that the spirit of the holy gods is in you and that you are skillful and have knowledge and wisdom.

Chapter 5.5:15: The advisers and magicians were brought in to read this writing and tell me what it means, but they could not discover the meaning.

Chapter 5.5:17: Daniel replied, Keep your gifts for yourself or give them to someone else. I will read for Your Majesty what has been written and tell you what it means.

Chapter 5.5:18: The Supreme God made your father Nebuchadnezzar a great king and gave him dignity and majesty.

Chapter 5.5:19: He was so great that people of all nations, races, and languages were afraid of him and trembled. If he wanted to kill someone, he did; if he wanted to keep someone alive, he did. He honored or disgraced anyone he wanted to.

Chapter 5.5:20: But because he became proud, stubborn, and cruel, he was removed from his royal throne and lost his place of honor.

Chapter 5.5:21: He was driven away from human society, and his mind became like that of an animal. Chapter 5.5:22: But you, his son, have not humbled yourself, even though you knew all this.

But you did not honor the God who determines whether you live or die and who controls everything you do.

Chapter 5.5:24: That is why God has sent the hand to write these words.

Chapter 5.5:29: Immediately Belshazzar ordered his servants to dress Daniel in a robe of royal purple and to hang a gold chain of honor around his neck. And he made him the third in power in the kingdom.

Chapter 5.5:30: That same night Belshazzar, the king of Babylonia, was killed;

Chapter 5.5:31: and Darius the Mede, who was then sixty-two years old, seized the royal power.

Chapter 7.7:1: In the first year that Belshazzar was king of Babylonia, I had a dream and saw a vision in the night. I wrote the dream down, and this is the record

Chapter 7.7:2: of what I saw that night: Winds were blowing from all directions and lashing the surface of the ocean.

Chapter 7.7:3: Four huge beasts came up out of the ocean, each one different from the others.

Chapter 7.7:4: The first one looked like a lion, but had wings like an eagle. While I was watching, the wings were torn off. The beast was lifted up and made to stand up straight. And then a human mind was given to it.

Chapter 7.7:5: The second beast looked like a bear standing on its hind legs. It was holding three ribs between its teeth, and a voice said to it, Go on, eat as much meat as you can!

Chapter 7.7:6: While I was watching, another beast appeared. It looked like a leopard, but on its back there were four wings, like the wings of a bird, and it had four heads. It had a look of authority about it.

Chapter 7.7:7: As I was watching, a fourth beast appeared. It was powerful, horrible, terrifying. With its huge iron teeth it crushed its victims, and then it trampled on them. Unlike the other beasts, it had ten horns.

Chapter 7.7:8: While I was staring at the horns, I saw a little horn coming up among the others. It tore out three of the horns that were already there. This horn had human eyes and a mouth that was boasting proudly.

Chapter 7.7:9: While I was looking, thrones were put in place. One who had been living forever sat down on one of the thrones. His clothes were white as snow, and his hair was like pure wool. His throne, mounted on fiery wheels, was blazing with fire,

Chapter 7.7:10: and a stream of fire was pouring out from it. There were many thousands of people there to serve him, and millions of people stood before him. The court began its session, and the books were opened.

Chapter 7.7:11: While I was looking, I could still hear the little horn bragging and boasting. As I watched, the fourth beast was killed, and its body was thrown into the flames and destroyed.

Chapter 7.7:12: The other beasts had their power taken away, but they were permitted to go on living for a limited time.

Chapter 7.7:13: During this vision in the night, I saw what looked like a human being. He was approaching me, surrounded by clouds, and he went to the one who had been living forever and was presented to him.

Chapter 7.7:14: He was given authority, honor, and royal power, so that the people of all nations, races, and languages would serve him. His authority would last forever, and his kingdom would never end.

Chapter 7.7:15: The visions I saw alarmed me, and I was deeply disturbed.

Chapter 7.7:16: I went up to one of those standing there and asked him to explain it all. So he told me the meaning.

Chapter 7.7:17: He said, These four huge beasts are four empires which will arise on earth.

Chapter 7.7:18: And the people of the Supreme God will receive royal power and keep it forever and ever.

Chapter 7.7:19: Then I wanted to know more about the fourth beast, which was not like any of the others—the terrifying beast which crushed its victims with its bronze claws and iron teeth and then trampled on them.

Chapter 7.7:20: And I wanted to know about the ten horns on its head and the horn that had come up afterward and had made three of the horns fall. It had eyes and a mouth and was boasting proudly. It was more terrifying than any of the others.

Chapter 7.7:21: While I was looking, that horn made war on God's people and conquered them.

Chapter 7.7:22: Then the one who had been living forever came and pronounced judgment in favor of the people of the Supreme God. The time had arrived for God's people to receive royal power.

Chapter 7.7:23: This is the explanation I was given: The fourth beast is a fourth empire that will be on the earth and will be different from all other empires. It will crush the whole earth and trample it down.

Chapter 7.7:24: The ten horns are ten kings who will rule that empire. Then another king will appear; he will be very different from the earlier ones and will overthrow three kings.

Chapter 7.7:25: He will speak against the Supreme God and oppress God's people. He will try to change their religious laws and festivals, and God's people will be under his power for three and a half years.

Chapter 7.7:26: Then the heavenly court will sit in judgment, take away his power, and destroy him completely.

Chapter 7.7:27: The power and greatness of all the kingdoms on earth will be given to the people of the Supreme God. Their royal power will never end, and all rulers on earth will serve and obey them.

Chapter 7.7:28: This is the end of the account. I was so frightened that I turned pale, and I kept everything to myself.

Chapter 8.8:1: In the third year that Belshazzar was king, I saw a second vision.

Chapter 8.8:2: In the vision I suddenly found myself in the walled city of Susa in the province of Elam. I was standing by the Ulai River,

Chapter 8.8:3: and there beside the river I saw a ram that had two long horns, one of which was longer and newer than the other.

Chapter 8.8:4: I watched the ram butting with his horns to the west, the north, and the south. No animal could stop him or escape his power. He did as he pleased and grew arrogant.

Chapter 8.8:5: While I was wondering what this meant, a goat came rushing out of the west, moving so fast that his feet didn't touch the ground. He had one prominent horn between his eyes.

Chapter 8.8:6: He came toward the ram, which I had seen standing beside the river, and rushed at him with all his force.

Chapter 8.8:7: I watched him attack the ram. He was so angry that he smashed into him and broke the two horns. The ram had no strength to resist. He was thrown to the ground and trampled on, and there was no one who could save him.

Chapter 8.8:8: The goat grew more and more arrogant, but at the height of his power his horn was broken. In its place four prominent horns came up, each pointing in a different direction.

Chapter 8.8:9: Out of one of these four horns grew a little horn, whose power extended toward the south and the east and toward the Promised Land.

Chapter 8.8:10: It grew strong enough to attack the army of heaven, the stars themselves, and it threw some of them to the ground and trampled on them.

Chapter 8.8:11: It even defied the Prince of the heavenly army, stopped the daily sacrifices offered to him, and ruined the Temple.

Chapter 8.8:12: People sinned there instead of offering the proper daily sacrifices, and true religion was thrown to the ground. The horn was successful in everything it did.

Chapter 8.8:13: Then I heard one angel ask another, How long will these things that were seen in the vision continue? How long will an awful sin replace the daily sacrifices? How long will the army of heaven and the Temple be trampled on?

Chapter 8.8:14: I heard the other angel answer, It will continue for 2,300 evenings and mornings, during which sacrifices will not be offered. Then the Temple will be restored.

Chapter 8.8:15: I was trying to understand what the vision meant, when suddenly someone was standing in front of me.

Chapter 8.8:16: I heard a voice call out over the Ulai River, Gabriel, explain to him the meaning of what he saw.

Chapter 8.8:17: Gabriel came and stood beside me, and I was so terrified that I fell to the ground. He said to me, Mortal man, understand the meaning. The vision has to do with the end of the world.

Chapter 8.8:18: While he was talking, I fell to the ground unconscious. But he took hold of me, raised me to my feet,

Chapter 8.8:19: and said, I am showing you what the result of God's anger will be. The vision refers to the time of the end.

Chapter 8.8:20: The ram you saw that had two horns represents the kingdoms of Media and Persia.

Chapter 8.8:21: The goat represents the kingdom of Greece, and the prominent horn between his eyes is the first king.

Chapter 8.8:22: The four horns that came up when the first horn was broken represent the four kingdoms into which that nation will be divided and which will not be as strong as the first kingdom.

Chapter 8.8:23: When the end of those kingdoms is near and they have become so wicked that they must be punished, there will be a stubborn, vicious, and deceitful king.

Chapter 8.8:24: He will grow strong—but not by his own power. He will cause terrible destruction and be successful in everything he does. He will bring destruction on powerful men and on God's own people.

Chapter 8.8:25: Because he is cunning, he will succeed in his deceitful ways. He will be proud of himself and destroy many people without warning. He will even defy the greatest King of all, but he will be destroyed without the use of any human power.

Chapter 8.8:26: This vision about the evening and morning sacrifices which has been explained to you will come true. But keep it secret now, because it will be a long time before it does come true.

Chapter 8.8:27: I was depressed and ill for several days. Then I got up and went back to the work that the king had assigned to me, but I was puzzled by the vision and could not understand it.

Chapter 9.9:1: Darius the Mede, who was the son of Xerxes, ruled over the kingdom of Babylonia.

Chapter 9.9:2: In the first year of his reign I was studying the sacred books and thinking about the seventy years that Jerusalem would be in ruins, according to what the Lord had told the prophet Jeremiah.

Chapter 9.9:3: And I prayed earnestly to the Lord God, pleading with him, fasting, wearing sackcloth, and sitting in ashes.

Chapter 9.9:4: I prayed to the Lord my God and confessed the sins of my people. I said, Lord God, you are great, and we honor you. You are faithful to your covenant and show constant love to those who love you and do what you command.

Chapter 9.9:5: We have sinned, we have been evil, we have done wrong. We have rejected what you commanded us to do and have turned away from what you showed us was right.

Chapter 9.9:6: We have not listened to your servants the prophets, who spoke in your name to our kings, our rulers, our ancestors, and our whole nation.

Chapter 9.9:7: You, Lord, always do what is right, but we have always brought disgrace on ourselves. This is true of all of us who live in Judea and in Jerusalem and of all the Israelites whom you scattered in countries near and far because they were unfaithful to you.

Chapter 9.9:8: Our kings, our rulers, and our ancestors have acted shamefully and sinned against you, Lord.

Chapter 9.9:9: You are merciful and forgiving, although we have rebelled against you.

Chapter 9.9:10: We did not listen to you, O Lord our God, when you told us to live according to the laws which you gave us through your servants the prophets.

Chapter 9.9:11: All Israel broke your laws and refused to listen to what you said. We sinned against you, and so you brought on us the curses that are written in the Law of Moses, your servant.

Chapter 9.9:12: You did what you said you would do to us and our rulers. You punished Jerusalem more severely than any other city on earth,

Chapter 9.9:13: giving us all the punishment described in the Law of Moses. But even now, O Lord our God, we have not tried to please you by turning from our sins or by following your truth.

Chapter 9.9:14: You, O Lord our God, were prepared to punish us, and you did, because you always do what is right, and we did not listen to you.

Chapter 9.9:15: O Lord our God, you showed your power by bringing your people out of Egypt, and your power is still remembered. We have sinned; we have done wrong.

Chapter 9.9:16: You have defended us in the past, so do not be angry with Jerusalem any longer. It is your city, your sacred hill. All the people in the neighboring countries look down on Jerusalem and on your people because of our sins and the evil our ancestors did.

Chapter 9.9:17: O God, hear my prayer and pleading. Restore your Temple, which has been destroyed; restore it so that everyone will know that you are God.

Chapter 9.9:18: Listen to us, O God; look at us and see the trouble we are in and the suffering of the city that bears your name. We are praying to you because you are merciful, not because we have done right.

Chapter 9.9:19: Lord, hear us. Lord, forgive us. Lord, listen to us, and act! In order that everyone will know that you are God, do not delay! This city and these people are yours.

Chapter 9.9:20: I went on praying, confessing my sins and the sins of my people Israel and pleading with the Lord my God to restore his holy Temple.

Chapter 9.9:21: While I was praying, Gabriel, whom I had seen in the earlier vision, came flying down to where I was. It was the time for the evening sacrifice to be offered.

Chapter 9.9:22: He explained, Daniel, I have come here to help you understand the prophecy.

Chapter 9.9:26: And at the end of that time God's chosen leader will be killed unjustly. The city and the Temple will be destroyed by the invading army of a powerful ruler. The end will come like a flood, bringing the war and destruction which God has prepared.

Chapter 10.10:1: In the third year that Cyrus was emperor of Persia, a message was revealed to Daniel, who is also called Belteshazzar. The message was true but extremely hard to understand. It was explained to him in a vision.

Chapter 10.10:3: I did not eat any rich food or any meat, drink any wine, or comb my hair until the three weeks were past.

Chapter 10.10:8: I was left there alone, watching this amazing vision. I had no strength left, and my face was so changed that no one could have recognized me.

Chapter 10.10:18: Once more he took hold of me, and I felt stronger.

Chapter 10.10:19: He said, God loves you, so don't let anything worry you or frighten you. When he had said this, I felt even stronger and said, Sir, tell me what you have to say. You have made me feel better.

Chapter 10.10:21: 20-He said, Do you know why I came to you? It is to reveal to you what is written in the Book of Truth. Now I have to go back and fight the guardian angel of Persia. Chapter 11.11:1: He is responsible for helping and defending me.

Chapter 11.11:3: Then a heroic king will appear. He will rule over a huge empire and do whatever he wants.

Chapter 11.11:4: But at the height of his power his empire will break up and be divided into four parts. Kings not descended from him will rule in his place, but they will not have the power that he had.

Chapter 11.11:8: He will carry back to Egypt the images of their gods and the articles of gold and silver dedicated to those gods. After several years of peace

Chapter 11.11:9: the king of Syria will invade Egypt, but he will be forced to retreat.

Chapter 11.11:10: The sons of the king of Syria will prepare for war and gather a large army. One of them will sweep on like a flood and attack an enemy fortress.

Chapter 11.11:11: In his anger the king of Egypt will go to war against the king of Syria and capture his huge army.

Chapter 11.11:12: He will be proud of his victory and of the many soldiers he has killed, but he will not continue to be victorious.

Chapter 11.11:13: The king of Syria will go back and gather a larger army than he had before. When the proper time comes, he will return with a large, well-equipped army.

Chapter 11.11:14: Then many people will rebel against the king of Egypt. And some violent people from your nation, Daniel, will rebel because of a vision they have seen, but they will be defeated.

Chapter 11.11:16: The Syrian invader will do with them as he pleases, without opposition. He will stand in the Promised Land and have it completely in his power.

Chapter 11.11:17: The king of Syria will plan an expedition, using his whole army. Then, in order to destroy his enemy's kingdom, he will make an alliance with him and offer him his daughter in marriage; but his plan will not succeed.

Chapter 11.11:22: Anyone who opposes him, even God's High Priest, will be swept away and wiped out.

Chapter 11.11:23: By making treaties, he will deceive other nations, and he will grow stronger and stronger, even though he rules only a small nation.

Chapter 11.11:24: He will invade a wealthy province without warning and will do things that none of his ancestors ever did. Then he will divide among his followers the goods and property he has captured in war. He will make plans to attack fortresses, but his time will soon run out.

Chapter 11.11:25: He will boldly raise a large army to attack the king of Egypt, who will prepare to fight back with a huge and powerful army. But the king of Egypt will be deceived and will not be successful.

Chapter 11.11:26: His closest advisers will ruin him. Many of his soldiers will be killed, and his army will be wiped out.

Chapter 11.11:27: Then the two kings will sit down to eat at the same table, but their motives will be evil, and they will lie to each other. They will not get what they want, because the time for it has not yet come.

Chapter 1.1:1: One day the Lord spoke to Jonah son of Amittai.

Chapter 1.1:4: But the Lord sent a strong wind on the sea, and the storm was so violent that the ship was in danger of breaking up.

Chapter 1.1:8: So they said to him, Now, then, tell us! Who is to blame for this? What are you doing here? What country do you come from? What is your nationality?

Chapter 1.1:9: I am a Hebrew, Jonah answered. I worship the Lord, the God of heaven, who made land and sea.

Chapter 1.1:11: The storm was getting worse all the time, so the sailors asked him, What should we do to you to stop the storm?

Chapter 1.1:12: Jonah answered, Throw me into the sea, and it will calm down. I know it is my fault that you are caught in this violent storm.

Chapter 1.1:13: Instead, the sailors tried to get the ship to shore, rowing with all their might. But the storm was becoming worse and worse, and they got nowhere.

Chapter 1.1:14: So they cried out to the Lord, O Lord, we pray, don't punish us with death for taking this man's life! You, O Lord, are responsible for all this; it is your doing.

Chapter 2.2:12: The Gentiles do not have the Law of Moses; they sin and are lost apart from the Law. The Jews have the Law; they sin and are judged by the Law.
