Chapter 2.2:14: The Gentiles do not have the Law; but whenever they do by instinct what the Law commands, they are their own law, even though they do not have the Law.

Chapter 2.2:15: Their conduct shows that what the Law commands is written in their hearts. Their consciences also show that this is true, since their thoughts sometimes accuse them and sometimes defend them.

Chapter 2.2:16: And so, according to the Good News I preach, this is how it will be on that Day when God through Jesus Christ will judge the secret thoughts of all.

Chapter 2.2:17: What about you? You call yourself a Jew; you depend on the Law and boast about God;

Chapter 2.2:18: you know what God wants you to do, and you have learned from the Law to choose what is right;

Chapter 2.2:19: you are sure that you are a guide for the blind, a light for those who are in darkness,

Chapter 2.2:20: an instructor for the foolish, and a teacher for the ignorant. You are certain that in the Law you have the full content of knowledge and of truth.

Chapter 2.2:21: You teach others—why don't you teach yourself? You preach, Do not steal—but do you yourself steal?

Chapter 2.2:22: You say, Do not commit adultery—but do you commit adultery? You detest idols—but do you rob temples?

Chapter 2.2:23: You boast about having God's law—but do you bring shame on God by breaking his law?

Chapter 2.2:24: The scripture says, Because of you Jews, the Gentiles speak evil of God.

Chapter 2.2:25: If you obey the Law, your circumcision is of value; but if you disobey the Law, you might as well never have been circumcised.

Chapter 2.2:26: If the Gentile, who is not circumcised, obeys the commands of the Law, will not God regard him as though he were circumcised?

Chapter 2.2:27: And so you Jews will be condemned by the Gentiles because you break the Law, even though you have it written down and are circumcised; but they obey the Law, even though they are not physically circumcised.

Chapter 2.2:28: After all, who is a real Jew, truly circumcised? It is not the man who is a Jew on the outside, whose circumcision is a physical thing.

Chapter 2.2:29: Rather, the real Jew is the person who is a Jew on the inside, that is, whose heart has been circumcised, and this is the work of God's Spirit, not of the written Law. Such a person receives praise from God, not from human beings.

Chapter 5.5:1: Now that we have been put right with God through faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.

Chapter 5.5:2: He has brought us by faith into this experience of God's grace, in which we now live. And so we boast of the hope we have of sharing God's glory!

Chapter 5.5:3: We also boast of our troubles, because we know that trouble produces endurance,

Chapter 5.5:4: endurance brings God's approval, and his approval creates hope.

Chapter 5.5:5: This hope does not disappoint us, for God has poured out his love into our hearts by means of the Holy Spirit, who is God's gift to us.

Chapter 5.5:6: For when we were still helpless, Christ died for the wicked at the time that God chose.

Chapter 5.5:7: It is a difficult thing for someone to die for a righteous person. It may even be that someone might dare to die for a good person.

Chapter 5.5:8: But God has shown us how much he loves us—it was while we were still sinners that Christ died for us!

Chapter 5.5:9: By his blood we are now put right with God; how much more, then, will we be saved by him from God's anger!

Chapter 5.5:10: We were God's enemies, but he made us his friends through the death of his Son. Now that we are God's friends, how much more will we be saved by Christ's life!

Chapter 5.5:11: But that is not all; we rejoice because of what God has done through our Lord Jesus Christ, who has now made us God's friends.

Chapter 5.5:12: Sin came into the world through one man, and his sin brought death with it. As a result, death has spread to the whole human race because everyone has sinned.

Chapter 5.5:13: There was sin in the world before the Law was given; but where there is no law, no account is kept of sins.

Chapter 5.5:14: But from the time of Adam to the time of Moses, death ruled over all human beings, even over those who did not sin in the same way that Adam did when he disobeyed God's command. Adam was a figure of the one who was to come.

Chapter 5.5:15: But the two are not the same, because God's free gift is not like Adam's sin. It is true that many people died because of the sin of that one man. But God's grace is much greater, and so is his free gift to so many people through the grace of the one man, Jesus Christ.

Chapter 5.5:16: And there is a difference between God's gift and the sin of one man. After the one sin, came the judgment of Guilty; but after so many sins, comes the undeserved gift of Not guilty!

Chapter 5.5:17: It is true that through the sin of one man death began to rule because of that one man. But how much greater is the result of what was done by the one man, Jesus Christ! All who receive God's abundant grace and are freely put right with him will rule in life through Christ.

Chapter 5.5:18: So then, as the one sin condemned all people, in the same way the one righteous act sets all people free and gives them life.

Chapter 5.5:19: And just as all people were made sinners as the result of the disobedience of one man, in the same way they will all be put right with God as the result of the obedience of the one man.

Chapter 5.5:20: Law was introduced in order to increase wrongdoing; but where sin increased, God's grace increased much more.

Chapter 5.5:21: So then, just as sin ruled by means of death, so also God's grace rules by means of righteousness, leading us to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.

Chapter 6.6:1: What shall we say, then? Should we continue to live in sin so that God's grace will increase?

Chapter 6.6:2: Certainly not! We have died to sin—how then can we go on living in it?

Chapter 6.6:3: For surely you know that when we were baptized into union with Christ Jesus, we were baptized into union with his death.

Chapter 6.6:4: By our baptism, then, we were buried with him and shared his death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from death by the glorious power of the Father, so also we might live a new life.

Chapter 6.6:5: For since we have become one with him in dying as he did, in the same way we shall be one with him by being raised to life as he was.

Chapter 6.6:6: And we know that our old being has been put to death with Christ on his cross, in order that the power of the sinful self might be destroyed, so that we should no longer be the slaves of sin.

Chapter 6.6:7: For when we die, we are set free from the power of sin.

Chapter 6.6:8: Since we have died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him.

Chapter 6.6:9: For we know that Christ has been raised from death and will never die again—death will no longer rule over him.

Chapter 6.6:10: And so, because he died, sin has no power over him; and now he lives his life in fellowship with God.

Chapter 6.6:11: In the same way you are to think of yourselves as dead, so far as sin is concerned, but living in fellowship with God through Christ Jesus.

Chapter 6.6:12: Sin must no longer rule in your mortal bodies, so that you obey the desires of your natural self.

Chapter 6.6:13: Nor must you surrender any part of yourselves to sin to be used for wicked purposes. Instead, give yourselves to God, as those who have been brought from death to life, and surrender your whole being to him to be used for righteous purposes.

Chapter 6.6:14: Sin must not be your master; for you do not live under law but under God's grace.

Chapter 6.6:15: What, then? Shall we sin, because we are not under law but under God's grace? By no means!

Chapter 6.6:16: Surely you know that when you surrender yourselves as slaves to obey someone, you are in fact the slaves of the master you obey—either of sin, which results in death, or of obedience, which results in being put right with God.

Chapter 6.6:17: But thanks be to God! For though at one time you were slaves to sin, you have obeyed with all your heart the truths found in the teaching you received.

Chapter 6.6:18: You were set free from sin and became the slaves of righteousness.

Chapter 6.6:19: I use everyday language because of the weakness of your natural selves. At one time you surrendered yourselves entirely as slaves to impurity and wickedness for wicked purposes. In the same way you must now surrender yourselves entirely as slaves of righteousness for holy purposes.

Chapter 6.6:20: When you were the slaves of sin, you were free from righteousness.

Chapter 6.6:21: What did you gain from doing the things that you are now ashamed of? The result of those things is death!

Chapter 6.6:22: But now you have been set free from sin and are the slaves of God. Your gain is a life fully dedicated to him, and the result is eternal life.

Chapter 6.6:23: For sin pays its wage—death; but God's free gift is eternal life in union with Christ Jesus our Lord.

Chapter 7.7:1: Certainly you will understand what I am about to say, my friends, because all of you know about law. The law rules over people only as long as they live.

Chapter 7.7:2: A married woman, for example, is bound by the law to her husband as long as he lives; but if he dies, then she is free from the law that bound her to him.

Chapter 7.7:3: So then, if she lives with another man while her husband is alive, she will be called an adulteress; but if her husband dies, she is legally a free woman and does not commit adultery if she marries another man.

Chapter 7.7:4: That is how it is with you, my friends. As far as the Law is concerned, you also have died because you are part of the body of Christ; and now you belong to him who was raised from death in order that we might be useful in the service of God.

Chapter 7.7:5: For when we lived according to our human nature, the sinful desires stirred up by the Law were at work in our bodies, and all we did ended in death.

Chapter 7.7:6: Now, however, we are free from the Law, because we died to that which once held us prisoners. No longer do we serve in the old way of a written law, but in the new way of the Spirit.

Chapter 7.7:7: Shall we say, then, that the Law itself is sinful? Of course not! But it was the Law that made me know what sin is. If the Law had not said, Do not desire what belongs to someone else, I would not have known such a desire.

Chapter 7.7:8: But by means of that commandment sin found its chance to stir up all kinds of selfish desires in me. Apart from law, sin is a dead thing.

Chapter 7.7:9: I myself was once alive apart from law; but when the commandment came, sin sprang to life,

Chapter 7.7:10: and I died. And the commandment which was meant to bring life, in my case brought death.

Chapter 7.7:11: Sin found its chance, and by means of the commandment it deceived me and killed me.

Chapter 7.7:12: So then, the Law itself is holy, and the commandment is holy, right, and good.

Chapter 7.7:13: But does this mean that what is good caused my death? By no means! It was sin that did it; by using what is good, sin brought death to me, in order that its true nature as sin might be revealed. And so, by means of the commandment sin is shown to be even more terribly sinful.

Chapter 7.7:14: We know that the Law is spiritual; but I am a mortal, sold as a slave to sin.

Chapter 7.7:15: I do not understand what I do; for I don't do what I would like to do, but instead I do what I hate.

Chapter 7.7:16: Since what I do is what I don't want to do, this shows that I agree that the Law is right.

Chapter 7.7:17: So I am not really the one who does this thing; rather it is the sin that lives in me.

Chapter 7.7:18: I know that good does not live in me—that is, in my human nature. For even though the desire to do good is in me, I am not able to do it.

Chapter 7.7:19: I don't do the good I want to do; instead, I do the evil that I do not want to do.

Chapter 7.7:20: If I do what I don't want to do, this means that I am no longer the one who does it; instead, it is the sin that lives in me.

Chapter 7.7:21: So I find that this law is at work: when I want to do what is good, what is evil is the only choice I have.

Chapter 7.7:22: My inner being delights in the law of God.

Chapter 7.7:23: But I see a different law at work in my body—a law that fights against the law which my mind approves of. It makes me a prisoner to the law of sin which is at work in my body.

Chapter 7.7:24: What an unhappy man I am! Who will rescue me from this body that is taking me to death?

Chapter 7.7:25: Thanks be to God, who does this through our Lord Jesus Christ! This, then, is my condition: on my own I can serve God's law only with my mind, while my human nature serves the law of sin.

Chapter 12.12:1: So then, my friends, because of God's great mercy to us I appeal to you: Offer yourselves as a living sacrifice to God, dedicated to his service and pleasing to him. This is the true worship that you should offer.

Chapter 12.12:2: Do not conform yourselves to the standards of this world, but let God transform you inwardly by a complete change of your mind. Then you will be able to know the will of God—what is good and is pleasing to him and is perfect.

Chapter 12.12:3: And because of God's gracious gift to me I say to every one of you: Do not think of yourself more highly than you should. Instead, be modest in your thinking, and judge yourself according to the amount of faith that God has given you.

Chapter 12.12:4: We have many parts in the one body, and all these parts have different functions.

Chapter 12.12:5: In the same way, though we are many, we are one body in union with Christ, and we are all joined to each other as different parts of one body.

Chapter 12.12:6: So we are to use our different gifts in accordance with the grace that God has given us. If our gift is to speak God's message, we should do it according to the faith that we have;

Chapter 12.12:7: if it is to serve, we should serve; if it is to teach, we should teach;

Chapter 12.12:8: if it is to encourage others, we should do so. Whoever shares with others should do it generously; whoever has authority should work hard; whoever shows kindness to others should do it cheerfully.

Chapter 12.12:9: Love must be completely sincere. Hate what is evil, hold on to what is good.

Chapter 12.12:10: Love one another warmly as Christians, and be eager to show respect for one another.

Chapter 12.12:11: Work hard and do not be lazy. Serve the Lord with a heart full of devotion.

Chapter 12.12:12: Let your hope keep you joyful, be patient in your troubles, and pray at all times.

Chapter 12.12:13: Share your belongings with your needy fellow Christians, and open your homes to strangers.

Chapter 12.12:14: Ask God to bless those who persecute you—yes, ask him to bless, not to curse.

Chapter 12.12:15: Be happy with those who are happy, weep with those who weep.

Chapter 12.12:16: Have the same concern for everyone. Do not be proud, but accept humble duties. Do not think of yourselves as wise.

Chapter 12.12:17: If someone has done you wrong, do not repay him with a wrong. Try to do what everyone considers to be good.

Chapter 12.12:18: Do everything possible on your part to live in peace with everybody.

Chapter 12.12:19: Never take revenge, my friends, but instead let God's anger do it. For the scripture says, I will take revenge, I will pay back, says the Lord.

Chapter 12.12:20: Instead, as the scripture says: If your enemies are hungry, feed them; if they are thirsty, give them a drink; for by doing this you will make them burn with shame.

Chapter 12.12:21: Do not let evil defeat you; instead, conquer evil with good.

Chapter 13.13:1: Everyone must obey state authorities, because no authority exists without God's permission, and the existing authorities have been put there by God.

Chapter 13.13:2: Whoever opposes the existing authority opposes what God has ordered; and anyone who does so will bring judgment on himself.

Chapter 13.13:3: For rulers are not to be feared by those who do good, but by those who do evil. Would you like to be unafraid of those in authority? Then do what is good, and they will praise you,

Chapter 13.13:4: because they are God's servants working for your own good. But if you do evil, then be afraid of them, because their power to punish is real. They are God's servants and carry out God's punishment on those who do evil.

Chapter 13.13:5: For this reason you must obey the authorities—not just because of God's punishment, but also as a matter of conscience.

Chapter 13.13:6: That is also why you pay taxes, because the authorities are working for God when they fulfill their duties.

Chapter 13.13:7: Pay, then, what you owe them; pay them your personal and property taxes, and show respect and honor for them all.

Chapter 13.13:8: Be under obligation to no one—the only obligation you have is to love one another. Whoever does this has obeyed the Law.

Chapter 13.13:9: The commandments, Do not commit adultery; do not commit murder; do not steal; do not desire what belongs to someone else—all these, and any others besides, are summed up in the one command, Love your neighbor as you love yourself.

Chapter 13.13:10: If you love others, you will never do them wrong; to love, then, is to obey the whole Law.

Chapter 13.13:11: You must do this, because you know that the time has come for you to wake up from your sleep. For the moment when we will be saved is closer now than it was when we first believed.

Chapter 13.13:12: The night is nearly over, day is almost here. Let us stop doing the things that belong to the dark, and let us take up weapons for fighting in the light.

Chapter 13.13:13: Let us conduct ourselves properly, as people who live in the light of day—no orgies or drunkenness, no immorality or indecency, no fighting or jealousy.

Chapter 13.13:14: But take up the weapons of the Lord Jesus Christ, and stop paying attention to your sinful nature and satisfying its desires.

Chapter 16.16:1: I recommend to you our sister Phoebe, who serves the church at Cenchreae.

Chapter 16.16:2: Receive her in the Lord's name, as God's people should, and give her any help she may need from you; for she herself has been a good friend to many people and also to me.

Chapter 16.16:3: I send greetings to Priscilla and Aquila, my fellow workers in the service of Christ Jesus;

Chapter 16.16:4: they risked their lives for me. I am grateful to them—not only I, but all the Gentile churches as well.

Chapter 16.16:5: Greetings also to the church that meets in their house. Greetings to my dear friend Epaenetus, who was the first in the province of Asia to believe in Christ.

Chapter 16.16:6: Greetings to Mary, who has worked so hard for you.

Chapter 16.16:7: Greetings also to Andronicus and Junia, fellow Jews who were in prison with me; they are well known among the apostles, and they became Christians before I did.

Chapter 16.16:8: My greetings to Ampliatus, my dear friend in the fellowship of the Lord.

Chapter 16.16:9: Greetings also to Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ's service, and to Stachys, my dear friend.

Chapter 16.16:10: Greetings to Apelles, whose loyalty to Christ has been proved. Greetings to those who belong to the family of Aristobulus.

Chapter 16.16:11: Greetings to Herodion, a fellow Jew, and to the Christians in the family of Narcissus.

Chapter 16.16:12: My greetings to Tryphaena and Tryphosa, who work in the Lord's service, and to my dear friend Persis, who has done so much work for the Lord.

Chapter 16.16:13: I send greetings to Rufus, that outstanding worker in the Lord's service, and to his mother, who has always treated me like a son.

Chapter 16.16:14: My greetings to Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and all the other Christians with them.

Chapter 16.16:15: Greetings to Philologus and Julia, to Nereus and his sister, to Olympas and to all of God's people who are with them.

Chapter 16.16:16: Greet one another with the kiss of peace. All the churches of Christ send you their greetings.

Chapter 16.16:17: I urge you, my friends: watch out for those who cause divisions and upset people's faith and go against the teaching which you have received. Keep away from them!

Chapter 16.16:18: For those who do such things are not serving Christ our Lord, but their own appetites. By their fine words and flattering speech they deceive innocent people.

Chapter 16.16:19: Everyone has heard of your loyalty to the gospel, and for this reason I am happy about you. I want you to be wise about what is good, but innocent in what is evil.

Chapter 16.16:20: And God, our source of peace, will soon crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.

Chapter 16.16:21: Timothy, my fellow worker, sends you his greetings; and so do Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, fellow Jews.

Chapter 16.16:22: I, Tertius, the writer of this letter, send you Christian greetings.

Chapter 16.16:23: My host Gaius, in whose house the church meets, sends you his greetings; Erastus, the city treasurer, and our brother Quartus send you their greetings.

Chapter 16.16:25: Let us give glory to God! He is able to make you stand firm in your faith, according to the Good News I preach about Jesus Christ and according to the revelation of the secret truth which was hidden for long ages in the past.

Chapter 16.16:26: Now, however, that truth has been brought out into the open through the writings of the prophets; and by the command of the eternal God it is made known to all nations, so that all may believe and obey.

Chapter 16.16:27: To the only God, who alone is all-wise, be glory through Jesus Christ forever! Amen.

Chapter 1.1:1: From Paul, whose call to be an apostle did not come from human beings or by human means, but from Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised him from death.

Chapter 1.1:2: All the believers who are here join me in sending greetings to the churches of Galatia:

Chapter 1.1:3: May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.

Chapter 1.1:4: In order to set us free from this present evil age, Christ gave himself for our sins, in obedience to the will of our God and Father.

Chapter 1.1:5: To God be the glory forever and ever! Amen.

Chapter 1.1:6: I am surprised at you! In no time at all you are deserting the one who called you by the grace of Christ, and are accepting another gospel.

Chapter 1.1:7: Actually, there is no other gospel, but I say this because there are some people who are upsetting you and trying to change the gospel of Christ.

Chapter 1.1:8: But even if we or an angel from heaven should preach to you a gospel that is different from the one we preached to you, may he be condemned to hell!

Chapter 1.1:9: We have said it before, and now I say it again: if anyone preaches to you a gospel that is different from the one you accepted, may he be condemned to hell!

Chapter 1.1:10: Does this sound as if I am trying to win human approval? No indeed! What I want is God's approval! Am I trying to be popular with people? If I were still trying to do so, I would not be a servant of Christ.

Chapter 1.1:11: Let me tell you, my friends, that the gospel I preach is not of human origin.

Chapter 1.1:12: I did not receive it from any human being, nor did anyone teach it to me. It was Jesus Christ himself who revealed it to me.

Chapter 1.1:13: You have been told how I used to live when I was devoted to the Jewish religion, how I persecuted without mercy the church of God and did my best to destroy it.

Chapter 1.1:14: I was ahead of most other Jews of my age in my practice of the Jewish religion, and was much more devoted to the traditions of our ancestors.

Chapter 1.1:15: But God in his grace chose me even before I was born, and called me to serve him. And when he decided

Chapter 1.1:16: to reveal his Son to me, so that I might preach the Good News about him to the Gentiles, I did not go to anyone for advice,

Chapter 1.1:17: nor did I go to Jerusalem to see those who were apostles before me. Instead, I went at once to Arabia, and then I returned to Damascus.

Chapter 1.1:18: It was three years later that I went to Jerusalem to obtain information from Peter, and I stayed with him for two weeks.

Chapter 1.1:19: I did not see any other apostle except James, the Lord's brother.

Chapter 1.1:20: What I write is true. God knows that I am not lying!

Chapter 1.1:21: Afterward I went to places in Syria and Cilicia.

Chapter 1.1:22: At that time the members of the churches in Judea did not know me personally.

Chapter 1.1:23: They knew only what others were saying: The man who used to persecute us is now preaching the faith that he once tried to destroy!

Chapter 1.1:24: And so they praised God because of me.

Chapter 2.2:1: Fourteen years later I went back to Jerusalem with Barnabas, taking Titus along with me.

Chapter 2.2:2: I went because God revealed to me that I should go. In a private meeting with the leaders I explained the gospel message that I preach to the Gentiles. I did not want my work in the past or in the present to be a failure.

Chapter 2.2:3: My companion Titus, even though he is Greek, was not forced to be circumcised,

Chapter 2.2:4: although some wanted it done. Pretending to be believers, these men slipped into our group as spies, in order to find out about the freedom we have through our union with Christ Jesus. They wanted to make slaves of us,

Chapter 2.2:5: but in order to keep the truth of the gospel safe for you, we did not give in to them for a minute.

Chapter 2.2:6: But those who seemed to be the leaders—I say this because it makes no difference to me what they were; God does not judge by outward appearances—those leaders, I say, made no new suggestions to me.

Chapter 2.2:7: On the contrary, they saw that God had given me the task of preaching the gospel to the Gentiles, just as he had given Peter the task of preaching the gospel to the Jews.

Chapter 2.2:8: For by God's power I was made an apostle to the Gentiles, just as Peter was made an apostle to the Jews.

Chapter 2.2:9: James, Peter, and John, who seemed to be the leaders, recognized that God had given me this special task; so they shook hands with Barnabas and me, as a sign that we were all partners. We agreed that Barnabas and I would work among the Gentiles and they among the Jews.

Chapter 2.2:10: All they asked was that we should remember the needy in their group, which is the very thing I have been eager to do.

Chapter 2.2:11: But when Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him in public, because he was clearly wrong.

Chapter 2.2:12: Before some men who had been sent by James arrived there, Peter had been eating with the Gentile believers. But after these men arrived, he drew back and would not eat with the Gentiles, because he was afraid of those who were in favor of circumcising them.

Chapter 2.2:13: The other Jewish believers also started acting like cowards along with Peter; and even Barnabas was swept along by their cowardly action.

Chapter 2.2:14: When I saw that they were not walking a straight path in line with the truth of the gospel, I said to Peter in front of them all, You are a Jew, yet you have been living like a Gentile, not like a Jew. How, then, can you try to force Gentiles to live like Jews?

Chapter 2.2:15: Indeed, we are Jews by birth and not Gentile sinners, as they are called.

Chapter 2.2:16: Yet we know that a person is put right with God only through faith in Jesus Christ, never by doing what the Law requires. We, too, have believed in Christ Jesus in order to be put right with God through our faith in Christ, and not by doing what the Law requires. For no one is put right with God by doing what the Law requires.

Chapter 2.2:17: If, then, as we try to be put right with God by our union with Christ, we are found to be sinners, as much as the Gentiles are—does this mean that Christ is serving the cause of sin? By no means!

Chapter 2.2:18: If I start to rebuild the system of Law that I tore down, then I show myself to be someone who breaks the Law.

Chapter 2.2:19: So far as the Law is concerned, however, I am dead—killed by the Law itself—in order that I might live for God. I have been put to death with Christ on his cross,

Chapter 2.2:20: so that it is no longer I who live, but it is Christ who lives in me. This life that I live now, I live by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave his life for me.

Chapter 2.2:21: I refuse to reject the grace of God. But if a person is put right with God through the Law, it means that Christ died for nothing!

Chapter 3.3:1: You foolish Galatians! Who put a spell on you? Before your very eyes you had a clear description of the death of Jesus Christ on the cross!

Chapter 3.3:2: Tell me this one thing: did you receive God's Spirit by doing what the Law requires or by hearing the gospel and believing it?

Chapter 3.3:3: How can you be so foolish! You began by God's Spirit; do you now want to finish by your own power?

Chapter 3.3:4: Did all your experience mean nothing at all? Surely it meant something!

Chapter 3.3:5: Does God give you the Spirit and work miracles among you because you do what the Law requires or because you hear the gospel and believe it?

Chapter 3.3:6: Consider the experience of Abraham; as the scripture says, He believed God, and because of his faith God accepted him as righteous.

Chapter 3.3:7: You should realize, then, that the real descendants of Abraham are the people who have faith.

Chapter 3.3:8: The scripture predicted that God would put the Gentiles right with himself through faith. And so the scripture announced the Good News to Abraham: Through you God will bless all people.

Chapter 3.3:9: Abraham believed and was blessed; so all who believe are blessed as he was.

Chapter 3.3:10: Those who depend on obeying the Law live under a curse. For the scripture says, Whoever does not always obey everything that is written in the book of the Law is under God's curse!

Chapter 3.3:11: Now, it is clear that no one is put right with God by means of the Law, because the scripture says, Only the person who is put right with God through faith shall live.

Chapter 3.3:12: But the Law has nothing to do with faith. Instead, as the scripture says, Whoever does everything the Law requires will live.

Chapter 3.3:13: But by becoming a curse for us Christ has redeemed us from the curse that the Law brings; for the scripture says, Anyone who is hanged on a tree is under God's curse.

Chapter 3.3:14: Christ did this in order that the blessing which God promised to Abraham might be given to the Gentiles by means of Christ Jesus, so that through faith we might receive the Spirit promised by God.

Chapter 3.3:15: My friends, I am going to use an everyday example: when two people agree on a matter and sign an agreement, no one can break it or add anything to it.

Chapter 3.3:16: Now, God made his promises to Abraham and to his descendant. The scripture does not use the plural descendants, meaning many people, but the singular descendant, meaning one person only, namely, Christ.

Chapter 3.3:17: What I mean is that God made a covenant with Abraham and promised to keep it. The Law, which was given four hundred and thirty years later, cannot break that covenant and cancel God's promise.

Chapter 3.3:18: For if God's gift depends on the Law, then it no longer depends on his promise. However, it was because of his promise that God gave that gift to Abraham.

Chapter 3.3:19: What, then, was the purpose of the Law? It was added in order to show what wrongdoing is, and it was meant to last until the coming of Abraham's descendant, to whom the promise was made. The Law was handed down by angels, with a man acting as a go-between.

Chapter 3.3:20: But a go-between is not needed when only one person is involved; and God is one.

Chapter 3.3:21: Does this mean that the Law is against God's promises? No, not at all! For if human beings had received a law that could bring life, then everyone could be put right with God by obeying it.

Chapter 3.3:22: But the scripture says that the whole world is under the power of sin; and so the gift which is promised on the basis of faith in Jesus Christ is given to those who believe.

Chapter 3.3:23: But before the time for faith came, the Law kept us all locked up as prisoners until this coming faith should be revealed.

Chapter 3.3:24: And so the Law was in charge of us until Christ came, in order that we might then be put right with God through faith.

Chapter 3.3:25: Now that the time for faith is here, the Law is no longer in charge of us.

Chapter 3.3:26: It is through faith that all of you are God's children in union with Christ Jesus.

Chapter 3.3:27: You were baptized into union with Christ, and now you are clothed, so to speak, with the life of Christ himself.

Chapter 3.3:28: So there is no difference between Jews and Gentiles, between slaves and free people, between men and women; you are all one in union with Christ Jesus.

Chapter 3.3:29: If you belong to Christ, then you are the descendants of Abraham and will receive what God has promised.

Chapter 5.5:1: Freedom is what we have—Christ has set us free! Stand, then, as free people, and do not allow yourselves to become slaves again.

Chapter 1.1:1: From Paul, who by God's will is an apostle of Christ Jesus— To God's people in Ephesus, who are faithful in their life in union with Christ Jesus:

Chapter 1.1:2: May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.

Chapter 1.1:3: Let us give thanks to the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ! For in our union with Christ he has blessed us by giving us every spiritual blessing in the heavenly world.

Chapter 1.1:4: Even before the world was made, God had already chosen us to be his through our union with Christ, so that we would be holy and without fault before him. Because of his love

Chapter 1.1:5: God had already decided that through Jesus Christ he would make us his children—this was his pleasure and purpose.

Chapter 1.1:6: Let us praise God for his glorious grace, for the free gift he gave us in his dear Son!

Chapter 1.1:7: For by the blood of Christ we are set free, that is, our sins are forgiven. How great is the grace of God,

Chapter 1.1:8: which he gave to us in such large measure! In all his wisdom and insight

Chapter 1.1:9: God did what he had purposed, and made known to us the secret plan he had already decided to complete by means of Christ.

Chapter 1.1:10: This plan, which God will complete when the time is right, is to bring all creation together, everything in heaven and on earth, with Christ as head.

Chapter 1.1:11: All things are done according to God's plan and decision; and God chose us to be his own people in union with Christ because of his own purpose, based on what he had decided from the very beginning.

Chapter 1.1:12: Let us, then, who were the first to hope in Christ, praise God's glory!

Chapter 1.1:13: And you also became God's people when you heard the true message, the Good News that brought you salvation. You believed in Christ, and God put his stamp of ownership on you by giving you the Holy Spirit he had promised.

Chapter 1.1:14: The Spirit is the guarantee that we shall receive what God has promised his people, and this assures us that God will give complete freedom to those who are his. Let us praise his glory!

Chapter 1.1:15: For this reason, ever since I heard of your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love for all of God's people,

Chapter 1.1:16: I have not stopped giving thanks to God for you. I remember you in my prayers

Chapter 1.1:17: and ask the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the glorious Father, to give you the Spirit, who will make you wise and reveal God to you, so that you will know him.

Chapter 1.1:18: I ask that your minds may be opened to see his light, so that you will know what is the hope to which he has called you, how rich are the wonderful blessings he promises his people,

Chapter 1.1:19: and how very great is his power at work in us who believe. This power working in us is the same as the mighty strength

Chapter 1.1:20: which he used when he raised Christ from death and seated him at his right side in the heavenly world.

Chapter 1.1:21: Christ rules there above all heavenly rulers, authorities, powers, and lords; he has a title superior to all titles of authority in this world and in the next.

Chapter 1.1:22: God put all things under Christ's feet and gave him to the church as supreme Lord over all things.

Chapter 1.1:23: The church is Christ's body, the completion of him who himself completes all things everywhere.

Chapter 2.2:1: In the past you were spiritually dead because of your disobedience and sins.

Chapter 2.2:2: At that time you followed the world's evil way; you obeyed the ruler of the spiritual powers in space, the spirit who now controls the people who disobey God.

Chapter 2.2:3: Actually all of us were like them and lived according to our natural desires, doing whatever suited the wishes of our own bodies and minds. In our natural condition we, like everyone else, were destined to suffer God's anger.

Chapter 2.2:4: But God's mercy is so abundant, and his love for us is so great,

Chapter 2.2:5: that while we were spiritually dead in our disobedience he brought us to life with Christ. It is by God's grace that you have been saved.

Chapter 2.2:6: In our union with Christ Jesus he raised us up with him to rule with him in the heavenly world.

Chapter 2.2:7: He did this to demonstrate for all time to come the extraordinary greatness of his grace in the love he showed us in Christ Jesus.

Chapter 2.2:8: For it is by God's grace that you have been saved through faith. It is not the result of your own efforts, but God's gift, so that no one can boast about it.

Chapter 2.2:9: For it is by God's grace that you have been saved through faith. It is not the result of your own efforts, but God's gift, so that no one can boast about it.

Chapter 2.2:10: God has made us what we are, and in our union with Christ Jesus he has created us for a life of good deeds, which he has already prepared for us to do.

Chapter 2.2:11: You Gentiles by birth—called the uncircumcised by the Jews, who call themselves the circumcised which refers to what men do to their bodies—remember what you were in the past.

Chapter 2.2:12: At that time you were apart from Christ. You were foreigners and did not belong to God's chosen people. You had no part in the covenants, which were based on God's promises to his people, and you lived in this world without hope and without God.

Chapter 2.2:16: By his death on the cross Christ destroyed their enmity; by means of the cross he united both races into one body and brought them back to God.

Chapter 2.2:17: So Christ came and preached the Good News of peace to all—to you Gentiles, who were far away from God, and to the Jews, who were near to him.

Chapter 2.2:18: It is through Christ that all of us, Jews and Gentiles, are able to come in the one Spirit into the presence of the Father.

Chapter 2.2:19: So then, you Gentiles are not foreigners or strangers any longer; you are now citizens together with God's people and members of the family of God.

Chapter 2.2:20: You, too, are built upon the foundation laid by the apostles and prophets, the cornerstone being Christ Jesus himself.

Chapter 2.2:21: He is the one who holds the whole building together and makes it grow into a sacred temple dedicated to the Lord.

Chapter 2.2:22: In union with him you too are being built together with all the others into a place where God lives through his Spirit.

Chapter 3.3:1: For this reason I, Paul, the prisoner of Christ Jesus for the sake of you Gentiles, pray to God.

Chapter 3.3:2: Surely you have heard that God in his grace has given me this work to do for your good.

Chapter 3.3:3: God revealed his secret plan and made it known to me. I have written briefly about this,

Chapter 3.3:4: and if you will read what I have written, you can learn about my understanding of the secret of Christ.

Chapter 3.3:5: In past times human beings were not told this secret, but God has revealed it now by the Spirit to his holy apostles and prophets.

Chapter 3.3:6: The secret is that by means of the gospel the Gentiles have a part with the Jews in God's blessings; they are members of the same body and share in the promise that God made through Christ Jesus.

Chapter 3.3:7: I was made a servant of the gospel by God's special gift, which he gave me through the working of his power.

Chapter 3.3:8: I am less than the least of all God's people; yet God gave me this privilege of taking to the Gentiles the Good News about the infinite riches of Christ,

Chapter 3.3:9: and of making all people see how God's secret plan is to be put into effect. God, who is the Creator of all things, kept his secret hidden through all the past ages,

Chapter 3.3:10: in order that at the present time, by means of the church, the angelic rulers and powers in the heavenly world might learn of his wisdom in all its different forms.

Chapter 3.3:11: God did this according to his eternal purpose, which he achieved through Christ Jesus our Lord.

Chapter 3.3:12: In union with Christ and through our faith in him we have the boldness to go into God's presence with all confidence.

Chapter 3.3:13: I beg you, then, not to be discouraged because I am suffering for you; it is all for your benefit.

Chapter 3.3:14: For this reason I fall on my knees before the Father,

Chapter 3.3:16: I ask God from the wealth of his glory to give you power through his Spirit to be strong in your inner selves,

Chapter 3.3:17: and I pray that Christ will make his home in your hearts through faith. I pray that you may have your roots and foundation in love,

Chapter 3.3:19: Yes, may you come to know his love—although it can never be fully known—and so be completely filled with the very nature of God.

Chapter 3.3:20: To him who by means of his power working in us is able to do so much more than we can ever ask for, or even think of:

Chapter 3.3:21: to God be the glory in the church and in Christ Jesus for all time, forever and ever! Amen.

Chapter 6.6:1: Children, it is your Christian duty to obey your parents, for this is the right thing to do.

Chapter 1.1:1: From Paul and Timothy, servants of Christ Jesus— To all God's people in Philippi who are in union with Christ Jesus, including the church leaders and helpers:

Chapter 1.1:2: May God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ give you grace and peace.

Chapter 1.1:3: I thank my God for you every time I think of you;

Chapter 1.1:4: and every time I pray for you all, I pray with joy

Chapter 1.1:5: because of the way in which you have helped me in the work of the gospel from the very first day until now.

Chapter 1.1:6: And so I am sure that God, who began this good work in you, will carry it on until it is finished on the Day of Christ Jesus.

Chapter 1.1:7: You are always in my heart! And so it is only right for me to feel as I do about you. For you have all shared with me in this privilege that God has given me, both now that I am in prison and also while I was free to defend the gospel and establish it firmly.

Chapter 1.1:8: God is my witness that I tell the truth when I say that my deep feeling for you all comes from the heart of Christ Jesus himself.

Chapter 1.1:9: I pray that your love will keep on growing more and more, together with true knowledge and perfect judgment,

Chapter 1.1:10: so that you will be able to choose what is best. Then you will be free from all impurity and blame on the Day of Christ.

Chapter 1.1:11: Your lives will be filled with the truly good qualities which only Jesus Christ can produce, for the glory and praise of God.

Chapter 1.1:12: I want you to know, my friends, that the things that have happened to me have really helped the progress of the gospel.

Chapter 1.1:13: As a result, the whole palace guard and all the others here know that I am in prison because I am a servant of Christ.

Chapter 1.1:14: And my being in prison has given most of the believers more confidence in the Lord, so that they grow bolder all the time to preach the message fearlessly.

Chapter 1.1:15: Of course some of them preach Christ because they are jealous and quarrelsome, but others from genuine good will.

Chapter 1.1:16: These do so from love, because they know that God has given me the work of defending the gospel.

Chapter 1.1:17: The others do not proclaim Christ sincerely, but from a spirit of selfish ambition; they think that they will make more trouble for me while I am in prison.

Chapter 1.1:18: It does not matter! I am happy about it—just so Christ is preached in every way possible, whether from wrong or right motives. And I will continue to be happy,

Chapter 1.1:19: because I know that by means of your prayers and the help which comes from the Spirit of Jesus Christ I shall be set free.

Chapter 1.1:20: My deep desire and hope is that I shall never fail in my duty, but that at all times, and especially right now, I shall be full of courage, so that with my whole being I shall bring honor to Christ, whether I live or die.

Chapter 1.1:21: For what is life? To me, it is Christ. Death, then, will bring more.

Chapter 1.1:22: But if by continuing to live I can do more worthwhile work, then I am not sure which I should choose.

Chapter 1.1:23: I am pulled in two directions. I want very much to leave this life and be with Christ, which is a far better thing;

Chapter 1.1:24: but for your sake it is much more important that I remain alive.

Chapter 1.1:25: I am sure of this, and so I know that I will stay. I will stay on with you all, to add to your progress and joy in the faith,

Chapter 1.1:26: so that when I am with you again, you will have even more reason to be proud of me in your life in union with Christ Jesus.

Chapter 1.1:27: Now, the important thing is that your way of life should be as the gospel of Christ requires, so that, whether or not I am able to go and see you, I will hear that you are standing firm with one common purpose and that with only one desire you are fighting together for the faith of the gospel.

Chapter 1.1:28: Don't be afraid of your enemies; always be courageous, and this will prove to them that they will lose and that you will win, because it is God who gives you the victory.

Chapter 1.1:29: For you have been given the privilege of serving Christ, not only by believing in him, but also by suffering for him.

Chapter 1.1:30: Now you can take part with me in the battle. It is the same battle you saw me fighting in the past, and as you hear, the one I am fighting still.

Chapter 3.3:20: We, however, are citizens of heaven, and we eagerly wait for our Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ, to come from heaven.

Chapter 3.3:21: He will change our weak mortal bodies and make them like his own glorious body, using that power by which he is able to bring all things under his rule.
